entries: When you reach 18th level, you can now hide even massive objects and crowds of people. When you use the concealment power, you can conceal an object that fits within a 300-foot cube—enough to hide a small city block.
And when you use the {@spell mass invisibility|Superheroic5E} power, you can obscure up to 30 people rather than six, and the duration of the power is 1 hour.

entries.name: Polymorphing Transformation
entries: You can instantly change your appearance. Some polymorphing heroes take on the appearance of others, infiltrating their enemies, while others alter their forms to have animal claws, gills, wings, and more. Finally, because of the evolving nature of their bodies, polymorphing heroes often can heal themselves at extraordinary rates.

entries.name: Polymorphing Transformation Powers
entries: Polymorphing Metamorphs know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Mimicry
entries: When you choose the polymorphing transformation at 1st level, you become adept at imitating others. You now have proficiency in {@skill Performance} if you did not have it already. If you do have it, you now have expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.
What's more, you can mimic the speech and accent of a person whom you have listened to for at least 1 minute.

entries.name: Improved Disguise Self
entries: At 6th level, when you use the {@spell disguise self} power, people who try to discern that you are disguised have disadvantage on their {@skill Investigation} checks.

entries.name: Improved Alter Self
entries: When you reach 13th level, your ability to alter your form improves. Now, when you use the {@spell alter self} power, you no longer need to maintain {@status concentration}. For you, the power now has a duration of 1 hour, but you can end the effect early if you choose.

entries.name: Forensic Transformation
entries: When you reach 18th level, your ability to mimic others reaches a new level of detail. When you use the {@spell alter self} or {@spell superior alter self|Superheroic5E} powers, you can change your fingerprints, erasing yours entirely or even mimicking someone else's if you have had a chance to study them carefully for ten minutes. Furthermore, you can alter your physiology enough to trick biometric scanners, modifying your retinas, heart rate, and even blood type.

entries.name: Symbiosis Transformation
entries: When you take the Symbiosis subclass, you determine that your Metamorph abilities are the result of an alien, extradimensional, or otherwise peculiar entity merging with you. Perhaps this entity is {@condition invisible}, hidden inside you, until it emerges to lash out at your foes. Or perhaps your symbiote is visible, attached to the back of your spine, and generating powers around you. Regardless, your symbiote provides you with many impressive and original powers.

Your symbiote is bonded with you and cannot normally be removed. Only through exceptional narrative means, and {@i with the consent of the player}, may a GM separate hero from symbiote, though some higher-level abilities allow the player to choose to separate host from symbiote. Separating the two effectively renders the hero a mundane human and the symbiote a slowly dying being. Such situations aside, the symbiosis hero effectively functions as a single being.

entries.name: Symbiosis Transformation
entries: Polymorphing Metamorphs know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Telepathic Experience
entries: When you choose the symbiosis transformation at 1st level, host and symbiote become inextricably linked. You both can communicate telepathically at will.

The symbiote brings a set of unusual experiences and perspectives as well, which benefit you. Choose one of the following skills: {@skill Mystic}, {@skill Science}, {@skill Survival}, or {@skill Technology}. You now have proficiency in this skill if you did not already, thanks to your symbiote.

entries.name: Symbiote Climbing
entries: At 1st level, your symbiote assists you in moving on vertical surfaces. You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Symbiotic Combat
entries: At 6th level, the symbiote begins to assert itself more forcefully to protect and support its host, participating directly in combat. When you make a weapon or power attack on your turn, you can use a bonus action to make a melee attack against a target within 10 feet of you, as a symbiotic tentacle erupts from you and strikes a target. Make a melee power attack against the target; on a hit, you deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 2d8} plus your power ability modifier. When you reach 14th level, the tentacle damage increases to {@dice 3d8} plus your power ability modifier.

Furthermore, when you are hit by a visible attack, you can use your reaction to generate a symbiotic shield to absorb some of the damage. When you do so, you reduce the amount of damage by your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Symbiotic Tentacles
entries: When you reach 13th level, your symbiote can extend its presence far beyond your body while remaining joined with the host.
As a bonus action, you can extend one symbiotic tentacle up to 30 feet. As a part of this and subsequent bonus actions, the tentacle can do the following things:

items: take the {@action Use an Object} action as a bonus action, both when you produce the tentacle and on subsequent turns
swing from structures as if from a grappling hook
make melee attacks as a bonus action, the same as with your Symbiotic Combat feature.
Your tentacle can reach around corners and behind cover.

entries: You can produce up to three such tentacles. When you take your bonus action to use your tentacles, you may only use one tentacle to make an attack; the other tentacles may instead use objects, attempt to grapple foes, and so on.

Your tentacles are a part of you, so when they take damage, you do. Nevertheless, they are resistant to all damage. If one is severed completely, it shrivels up and disappears, leaving only a residue behind.

entries.name: Symbiotic Independence
entries: When you reach 18th level, your symbiote gains the ability to leave its host and move around on its own. You control both the symbiote and the host when this occurs.

When the two separate, the symbiote and host both use your statistics, except that each has half of the HP, rounded down, that you had at the time of separation, and neither can use any powers until they rejoin. Also, the symbiote retains your climbing speed whereas the host loses it, while the symbiote loses the ability to speak and the host retains it. Finally, the symbiote can squeeze through spaces as small as one inch.

If either the symbiote or the host fall to zero HP, but remain alive, the other gains three levels of {@condition exhaustion} and must immediately make its way back to the other. If they manage to enter the same space, they combine their total HP and regain consciousness but retain the levels of {@condition exhaustion}.
I shall name it The Ring and they shall serve my purposes so that they seem to be serving themselves...

entries.name: {@class Mystic|Superheroic5E}
entries: Elemental heroes tap fundamental forces and elements of the universe, like gravity or heat. Mystic heroes, however, access powers more eldritch and arcane, but no less real and potent.

Whereas Elementalists might shoot ice or light, the Mystics, on the other hand, use subtler, stranger methods. Some are witches, hexing foes, while others study the ways of the arcane. A few deal with the spirits, perhaps even with archetypes like Life or Death itself. These eerie powers make Mystic heroes uncanny and unpredictable.

entries.name: Origin & Nature
entries: Some Mystic heroes are born into their power, inheriting it from an ancient bloodline or being born under the right astrological signs. Many more, however, gain access through study and sacrifice. Perhaps you dedicated years of your life to studying ancient grimoires and practicing spells. Or maybe you serve an entity from beyond space and time. Indeed, you might even have had to sacrifice something valuable—love, life, knowledge—to gain your abilities.
However, you gained them, you now possess dark and mysterious powers at your fingertips.

entries.name: Creating a Mystic
entries: Mystics are each unique in many ways, but they can be grouped into three kinds. When making a Mystic hero, choose a mystic path to walk; {@b arcane}, {@b eldritch}, or {@b primordial}. Arcane heroes study the laws and practices of magic; eldritch Mystics embrace eerie, supernatural forces fell and strange; and primordial Mystic heroes channel the fundamental energies of life and death. Your choice of mystic path determines what some of your superpowers will be, as well as grants you special benefits in certain circumstances.

entries.name: Class Features
entries: As an Mystic superhero, you gain the following class features.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: {@bold Hit Dice}: {@dice 1d8} per level
{@bold Hit Points at 1st Level}: 18 + your Constitution modifier
{@bold Hit Points at Higher Levels}: {@dice 1d8} (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Martial Expert level after 1st
{@bold Saving Throws}: Intelligence and Charisma

entries.name: Mystic Power
entries: At 1st level, your studies have granted you access to another plane of existence, one from which you can draw power.

entries.name: At Will Powers
entries: At 1st level, you know two at will powers from the Mystic or General power lists. You learn additional at will powers at higher levels, as shown in the at will powers column of the Mystic table.

entries.name: Powers Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level powers from the Mystic or General power lists.
The Leveled Powers Known column of the Mystic table shows when you learn more powers of your choice. Each of these powers must be of a level for which you have slots.

entries.name: Leveled Power Slots
entries: The Mystic table shows how many power slots are available for your powers at each level. To use one of these powers, you must expend a slot of the power's level or higher. You regain all expended 1st through 8th level slots when you finish a short or long rest. You regain any expended 9th level power slots when you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Power Ability
entries: Intelligence is your power ability for your superpowers since your access to power occurs through study and the comprehension of challenging truths. Use your Intelligence skill whenever a power refers to your power ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the save DC for a power you use and when making an attack roll with one.
{@b Power save DC =} 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
{@b Power attack modifier =} your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

entries.name: Mystic Path
entries: Which path you walk in your practice determines the nature of your powers. At 1st level, you must select your path: {@b arcane}, {@b eldritch}, or {@b primordial}. Your choice grants you several unique abilities, as well as features at 1st level and again at 6th, 10th, and 18th level. The three path choices are described near the end of the Mystic class description, before the list of invocations.

entries.name: Mystic Path Powers
entries: Each path has a list of powers that you gain at the Mystic levels noted in the path description. Once you gain a path power, it doesn't count against the number of powers known.

entries.name: Invocations
entries: In your study of occult lore or perhaps in your connection to your Mystic practices, you have unearthed Mystic invocations, fragments of forbidden knowledge that imbue you with an abiding superpowered ability.

At 2nd level, you gain two mystic invocations of your choice. Your invocation options are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain Mystic levels, you gain additional invocations of your choice, as shown in the Invocations Known column of the Mystic table.
Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the invocations you know and replace it with another invocation that you could learn at that level.
The list of available invocations can be found at the end of the Mystic class description, below.

entries.name: Supernatural Knowledge
entries: When you reach 2nd level, you gain proficiency in the Mystic skill. If you already have proficiency in it already, you now have expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.

entries.name: Mystic Boon
entries: At 3rd level, your otherworldly source of power bestows a gift upon you for your loyal service or because of your growing connection. You gain one of the features below. Each of these choices grants an additional feature at 9th, 15th, and 20th levels.

When you reach 3rd level, you must choose which boon you wish to receive. The Boon of the Tome has a scholarly focus, as the hero comes to learn a little bit about a wide variety of different powers. The Boon of the Avatar, however, concentrates your connection to your specific mystic path. In picking between the two, ask if you'd rather have a wide range of low-level powers from different sources, or if you'd prefer to focus and specialize in your chosen superpower profile, becoming exceptional at it

entries.name: Boon of the Tomb
entries: You study the art of the arcane, becoming a dilettante of a wide variety of magics hidden and dangerous. You create a Mystical Text—perhaps a grimoire, scroll, or other form of text. When you gain this feature, choose three at will powers from any superpower list (the three needn't be from the same list). While the book is on your person, you can use those powers at will. They don't count against your number of at will powers known.

If you lose your Mystic Book, you can perform a 1-hour ceremony to receive a replacement from your source of power. This ceremony can be performed during a short or long rest, and it destroys the previous book. The book turns to ash when you die.
In addition, you become more emersed in the occult. When you make a Mystic check, you roll with advantage.

At 9th level, you receive an additional mystic boon. you may add two 1st or 2nd level powers from any superpower list to your Mystical Text. As long as you have your Mystical Text with you, these powers count as reflexive powers for you. You cannot expend power slots to use these powers at higher levels, however. They don't count against your total number of powers known.

When you reach 15th level, your Mystical Text imbues you with the wisdom of the ages. Now, you can add half your proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check you make that doesn't already include your proficiency bonus.

At 20th level, your familiarity with all forms of superpowered and supernatural energies is unparalleled. With great effort, you can now capture and redirect superpowered attacks. When you are targeted with a superpower by a visible foe who is within 60 feet, you can use your reaction to reflect the power back at the original power user, as though you had used the power yourself. If the reflected power requires an attack roll or save, those rolls must be made using your power attack modifier or save DC.
This takes massive effort, however, so, once you have done this, you cannot do again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Boon of the Avatar
entries: Your contact with otherworldly forces is more than just scholarly; it is immersive. As such, you gradually come to embody more and more of your mystic path, until you truly become a specialist in your power.

When you gain this feature, you may select an additional at will power and an additional 1st level power from the Mystic power list. These powers do not count against your numbers of at will or leveled powers known. When you use the 1st level power, you must still expend a slot as normal.

At 9th level, channeling your Mystic powers bolsters you. When you use a power from your mystic path powers table, you gain temporary HP equal to your proficiency bonus. Furthermore, when you use a power listed in your Mystic path powers table that requires an attack roll or save, you may add +1 to the attack roll or save DC.

When you reach 15th level, the power flowing through you reinforces your existing strengths. Choose two skills you have proficiency in. When you roll these skills, you may add double your proficiency bonus.

At 20th level, you truly become the apotheosis of your Mystic path. When you use a power from your mystic path powers table that requires an attack roll or save, you may roll a {@dice 1d4 + 1}, rather than the +1 you gained at 9th level, and add it to the attack roll or power save DC.

entries.name: Reflexive Powers
entries: Starting at 3rd level, 1st-level power use is now reflexive for you. This means that you have a limitless supply of 1st-level power slots. If you wish to use abilities at higher level, however, you must expend a higher-level slot as normal.
As your heroes level up, the levels at which they can use their powers reflexively also increases. [See "Reflexive Powers Use Example" sidebar.]
Consult the chart above to see when heroes gain the ability to use higher-level powers reflexively

entries.name: Third Eye
entries: When you reach 5th level, your connection to otherworldly energies grants you the ability to see things no one else can see. You now have {@sense darkvision} to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, its range extends by 60 feet. You can see in darkness as if the darkness were dim light, though you cannot discern color, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Eerie Trance
entries: At 13th level, you can enter a meditative trance, gaining insight and protection. If you remain {@condition prone} with a speed of zero, you gain the benefit of the see invisibility, force armor, and sanctuary powers, even if you do not know these powers, as well as {@sense blindsight} to a range of 10 feet.

entries.name: Mystic Paths
entries: There are many arcane, primordial, and eldritch paths one might walk, and many otherworldly fonts of power that mortals might tap. The paths here briefly describe several such practices.

entries.name: Arcane Mystic Path
entries: Perhaps you study the ancient ways of the arcane, reading spells in dusty tomes and manipulating the fundamental principles of reality. You may know the true names of things, the forbidden words in the first language, or the sigils of power to unmake and alter the seams of existence. Maybe you draw mandalas, practice alchemy, or meditate on higher planes of existence. Whatever your technique, you perform miraculous, magical, mystical acts beyond the reach of mundane mortals.

entries.name: Arcane Path Powers
entries: Arcane Mystic know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Esoteric Research
entries: When you choose to walk this path at 1st level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Investigation} skill. If you already have it, you gain expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.
You additionally have advantage on rolls to detect superpowered individuals within 30 feet of you, as their nature causes ripples in the energies ebbing and flowing around you.

entries.name: Intimations of the Future
entries: When you reach 6th level, your attunement to the fabric of reality allows you to detect ripples of events yet to come. When you are targeted by an attack by a visible foe, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on their attack roll.

entries.name: Hermetic Ward
entries: At 10th level, your study of the arcane allows you to generate a protective field of magical energy around you. Whenever you spend 1 minute in meditation or complete a short or long rest, you gain temporary HP equal to your Mystic level.
As a reaction when a creature within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can share your ward with them. Once the ward's temporary HP are depleted, damage is dealt to the creature as normal.

entries.name: Sight Beyond Sight
entries: When you reach 18th level, your contact with the threads of reality around you reaches a pinnacle. You are now under the effect of the {@spell true seeing} power at all times, even if you do not know the power.

entries.name: Eldrich Mystic Path
entries: Some things were not meant to be known by feeble human minds; some beings lie beyond what can be conceived. These unnamable entities sometimes brush against human experience, shattering and warping it irrevocably. Your source of power may be one such and you are forever changed. Or perhaps, rather than having an ineffable eldritch entity as your origin, you instead walk a witchy path, connecting to the peculiar and the mysterious here on Earth. Maybe you have tapped into dark powers through incantation and spell. Either way, you walk on the darker, stranger side of things and draw power from a source that would terrify others.

entries.name: Eldrich Path Powers
entries: Eldrich Mystic know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Familiar
entries: When you choose this path at 1st level, you gain an otherworldly companion. This companion takes the form of a common animal but is in fact an instantiation of your eldritch practices. You now know the {@spell find familiar} power. The spell doesn't count against your number of powers known.

When you use this power, you can choose from a wider range of creatures. You can select any non-humanoid creature with a challenge rating of ½ or lower. Additionally, when you take the {@action Attack} action, you can forgo one of your own attacks to allow your familiar to make one attack of its own with its reaction

entries.name: Eerie Aura
entries: At 6th level, your connection to eldritch forces grants you an unsettling countenance. You now have advantage on saves against the {@condition frightened} condition.

Furthermore, as an action, you can emanate a sense of dread or deep discomfort. Every creature within 30 feet of you must make a Charisma save against your power save DC or be {@condition frightened} until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Empowered Familiar
entries: When you reach 10th level, your eldritch connection to your familiar grows. Now, the range out to which you can now telepathically communicate with your familiar extends to the whole planet.

As an action, you can also switch places with your familiar while you are in telepathic communication with it (assuming there is room for you at the familiar's location). Once you have used this ability, you cannot do so again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Impossible Knowledge
entries: When you reach 18th level, you connection to the uncanny or otherworldly realms have fully permeated your being, granting you insights into things you could not possibly know.
As an action, you can use the legend lore power without expending a slot even if you do not know the power, and even if the target is not of great importance.

entries.name: Primordial Mystic Path
entries: You may receive your powers from a being that embodies some aspect of Life or Death itself. Or perhaps you embody the force of vitality or entropy that decays and disassembles everything in the universe. Despite what some might think, these origins are not inherently good or evil, as the passage from birth to death befalls all beings. The path you walk may be one in service to a pantheon of gods, a worship of nature, or communion with Life itself. On the other hand, you might serve a psychopomp who ferries the dead to the afterlife or be able to access the natural entropy of the universe. Whatever the nature of your path, you connect and commune with a primordial force of life and death in a way no others can.

entries.name: Primordial Path Powers
entries: Primordial Mystic know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.caption: Primordial Path Powers
rows: {@spell chill of the grave|Superheroic5E}, {@spell bestow curse}

entries: When you choose this path at 1st level, you gain access to the raw forces of life or death. Choose either radiant or necrotic damage. You have resistance to this kind of damage.

Further, you know the {@spell primordial flame} at will power. This power does not count toward your total number of at will powers known. When you use this power, you deal the damage type you chose to be resistant to.

entries.name: Vitality Siphon
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to tap the flow of life force as it slips away. When you reduce a hostile creature to 0 HP, you gain temporary HP equal to your Intelligence modifier + your Mystic level (minimum of 1).

entries.name: Apprentice of Life and Death
entries: When you reach 10th level, your attunement to life and death strengthens. You have advantage on death saves.
You are now also immune to the damage type you chose as your Primordial Affinity at 1st level.

entries.name: Avatar of Life and Death
entries: At 18th level, you achieve mastery over the powers of mortality. You no longer need to eat, drink, or breathe and you have resistance to poison damage and advantage on saves against the {@condition poisoned} condition.
Finally, when you drop to 0 HP, you can choose to drop to 1 hit point instead. Once you have used this ability, you cannot do so again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Mystic Invocations
entries: Note: {@i if a Mystic Invocation grants you use of a power, it does not count against your total number of powers known or prepared and you may only use it at its lowest level.}
{@optfeature Agonizing Power|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Armor of Shadows}
{@optfeature Ascendant Step}
{@optfeature Incarnation of the Avatar|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Beast Speech}
{@optfeature Beguiling Influence}
{@optfeature Bewitching Whispers|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Devil's Sight}
{@optfeature Dreadful Word|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Eyes of the Rune Keeper}
{@optfeature Fiendish Vigor}
{@optfeature Font of the Origin|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Gaze of Two Minds}
{@optfeature Grasping Touch|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Intuitions of Ancient Secrets|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Mask of Many Faces}
{@optfeature Master of Myriad Forms}
{@optfeature Minions of Chaos}
{@optfeature Mire the Mind}
{@optfeature Misty Visions}
{@optfeature Mythic Spear|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature One with Shadows}
{@optfeature Oppressive Enchantment|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Otherworldly Leap}
{@optfeature Repelling Blast}
{@optfeature Sculptor of Flesh}
{@optfeature Sign of Ill Omen}
{@optfeature Thief of Five Fates}
{@optfeature Visions of Distant Realms}
{@optfeature Whispers of the Grave}
{@optfeature Witch Sight}

entries.name: {@class Special Agent|Superheroic5E}
entries: Most heroes have superpowers, either from superpowered physiologies, super-advanced technology, decades of intensive martial arts training, or, occasionally, from a potent artifact. A few brave mortals lack superpowers, yet still fight along with the other heroes. They bring know-how, grit, and unique training to bear to fight for what they believe in.

entries.name: Origin & Nature
entries: Special Agents fight with heroes and against dangerous threats as a career choice. Most start off in a military, police, espionage, security, or investigative positions and are then hand-picked to join a specialized task force that deals with superpowered friends and foes.

Perhaps you worked for a government and may still. Or maybe you work for an international organization, either publicly known, like the United Nations, or a secret group dedicated to protecting Earth from superpowered threats.

Regardless of your career path and the nature of your associated organization, you are largely a free agent now, able to go your own way and make your own choices. You must check in periodically with your organization and may receive orders, information, and support occasionally, but for the most part you are on your own.

entries.name: Creating a Special Agent
entries: Special Agents are people dedicated to their careers as protectors of the innocent or enforcers of justice. Decide what kind of background you had that led you to become an agent. Where you a police officer? A soldier? A revolutionary? A spy?

Next, work with your GM to describe your chosen organization. You can use a real-world one or create your own, but it's probably best if your position with the organization is unusual, allowing you the wide latitude to play as you prefer, without too many regulations or frequent orders from above limiting play.

Finally, choose your Special Agent's division: {@b investigator}, {@b operator}, or {@b soldier}. Investigators fight crime, look for clues, track down leads, and solve mysteries. Operators tend to work from the shadows, gathering intel as spies and experts in infiltration. Soldiers prefer a more direct approach, with expertise in combat tactics, weaponry, and explosives.

entries.name: Class Features
entries: As a Special Agent superhero, you gain the following class features.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: {@bold Hit Dice}: {@dice 1d10} per level
{@bold Hit Points at 1st Level}: 20 + your Constitution modifier
{@bold Hit Points at Higher Levels}: {@dice 1d10} (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per Martial Expert level after 1st
{@bold Saving Throws}: Dexterity and Charisma

entries.name: Expertise
entries: At 1st level, choose any two skill or tool proficiencies. You now have proficiency in them, if you did not before, as well as expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 6th level, you can choose any two more proficiencies to gain this benefit.

entries.name: Field Medic
entries: Your training allows you to apply first aid and treat wounds in the field. You have a supply of bandages and other materials that you can replenish when you take a long rest. With that pool of supplies, you can restore a total number of HP equal to your Special Agent level × 5.
As an action, you can touch a creature and apply a bandage, administer a drug, or otherwise treat a wound, to restore a number of HP to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in your pool.

Alternatively, you can expend 5 HP from your pool of supplies to cure the target of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting it. You can cure multiple diseases and neutralize multiple poisons with a single use of Field Medic, expending HP separately for each one. This feature has no effect on undead or constructs.

entries.name: Division
entries: When you become a Special Agent at 1st level, you choose or are assigned to a division, becoming an investigator, a soldier, or an operator.
Your choice grants you division specialization abilities and other features when you choose it at 1st level. It also grants you additional benefits at 3rd, 6th, 9th, 13th, and 17th levels.

entries.name: Special Attack
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you know how to deal more effective attacks. Your choice of division determines when you can make a special attack. Your special attack allows you to deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack once per turn. The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Special {@action Attack} column of the Special Agent table.

entries.name: Cunning Action
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} action.

entries.name: Broad Training
entries: Also at 2nd level, you can add half your proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check you make that doesn't already include your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 3rd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
{@optfeature Archery|phb|Ranged}
{@optfeature Defense}
{@optfeature Dueling}
{@optfeature Two-Weapon Fighting}

entries.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

entries.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: Starting at 5th level, when a visible attacker hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

entries.name: Evasion
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a grenade blast. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity save to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the save, and only half damage if you fail

entries.name: Reliable Talent
entries: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

entries.name: Blindsense
entries: Starting at 14th level, if you can hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or {@condition invisible} creature within 10 feet of you.

entries.name: Slippery Mind
entries: By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saves.

entries.name: Elusive
entries: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target in range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the {@dice d20} roll as a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Agent Division: Investigator
entries: You specialize in investigating crimes, solving mysteries, and uncovering the truth, no matter the cost.

entries.name: Special Attack: Assess
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you can use your bonus action to observe your foes in combat and find their weaknesses. The foes must be visible for you to assess them. This assessment take a few moments, so you do not gain its benefit until the round after you perform it. Once per turn after your assessment, you can deal your Special {@action Attack} damage to one assessed creature that you hit with an attack, as long as you are not attacking with disadvantage. This benefit applies only to this combat; you must reassess foes if you encounter them in a future combat.

If new creatures arrive or become visible during the combat, you may use another bonus action to assess these new foes, though you do not gain the benefit of this assessment until the round after you perform it. Assessing new creatures does not prevent you from dealing your Special {@action Attack} damage to foes you have already assessed in that combat.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Special {@action Attack} column of the Special Agent table.

entries.name: Investigator's Mind
entries: When you choose the Investigator division, you establish that you have a mind for solving mysteries. You have proficiency in {@skill Investigation}, if you did not before, and when you roll an {@skill Investigation} skill check, you do so with Expertise, adding your proficiency bonus twice to the roll.
What's more, you have a photographic memory and can recall things you have experienced with perfect accuracy within the past month.

entries.name: Forensic Sense
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your powers of observation and inference increase beyond the limits of human ability. When surveying an area, you notice otherwise undetectable details that reveal what has happened there recently. You get a sense of how many people have been in the area, and how long ago, as well as a general idea of what they were doing. You can usually find a stray hair, footprint, or fingerprint as well. By walking around an environment, you can detect immediately what a dedicated forensic team would need hours of careful analysis to discover. If a roll is called for to uncover clues, you have Expertise, which means that you add your proficiency bonus twice, as well as advantage.

entries.name: Additional Fighting Style
entries: When selecting your fighting style at 3rd level, you have the additional option available to you to choose:
{@optfeature Street Fighter|Superheroic5E}

entries.name: Sharp Eye
entries: Also at 3rd level, your eye for detail improves. You now have proficiency in {@skill Perception}, if you did not before, or Expertise if you already have proficiency in it.

entries.name: Investigative Experience
entries: At 6th level, your {@b Forensic Sense} reaches new heights. You not only notice footprints or tire tracks or fibers that others miss, but you also recognize their origin. For example, you can identify the brand of shoe, make and model of car, or kind of material that are responsible for such clues. When you examine evidence, you can reach accurate conclusions that a forensic researcher might need a week to uncover. If a roll is called for to analyze evidence you have found, you have advantage as well as Expertise, which means that you add your proficiency bonus twice. The GM can provide the relevant details.

entries.name: Reliable Intuition
entries: Also at 6th level, your ability to read people improves. You now have proficiency in {@skill Insight}, if you did not before, or Expertise if you already have proficiency in it.

entries.name: Mental Reenactment
entries: At 9th level, you can analyze a location and fully understand the most recent series of events that has transpired there. If you spend 1 minute examining a 30-foot square area, not only can tell who has been here and what in general they were doing, but you can visualize a reenactment of the scene, watching it unfold in your mind like a movie. This allows you to understand exactly what happened, blow-by-blow, rather than stopping at more general conclusions. The GM must truthfully describe the most recent significant series of events that occurred at the location, though details that might not leave a trace, like what an assailant's face looked like or what was said, would not be included.

entries.name: Web of Contacts
entries: When you reach 13th level, your experience as an investigator begins to pay off. Now, whenever you need inside information, access to a restricted area, or someone to persuade the prosecutor to drop charges, you know someone who can help. Once a day, you can contact someone to gain some inside-information, including sensitive or confidential info. Once a week, you can gain access to a restricted area or can receive a cache of rare or contraband supplies. And once a month, you can get charges dropped, up to and including manslaughter.

entries.name: Complete Forenic Analysis
entries: When you reach 17th level, you gain the know-how and ability of a complete forensic team. If you spend 10 minutes examining a 30-foot square area, you can find and analyze fingerprints and blood samples in the field as if you had weeks of work from a forensics lab. Simply by touching a drop of blood, for example, you can identify its blood type, how long ago it was spilled, and the age and sex of its owner. Similarly, by simply examining a bullet hole, you immediately know the kind of weapon that fired the bullet and the location of the shooter. You can even recognize fingerprints that you have seen before.

entries.name: Agent Division: Operator
entries: Your area of specialization focuses on covert operations, espionage, infiltration, and even, perhaps, wetwork.

entries.name: Special Attack: Sneak Attack
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.
You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't {@condition incapacitated}, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Special {@action Attack} column of the Special Agent table.

entries.name: Second-Story Work
entries: When you join the operator division at 1st level, you are trained how to climb faster than normal; climbing no longer costs you extra movement.
In addition, when you make a running jump, the distance you cover increases by the number of feet equal to your Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Fast Hands
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use the bonus action granted by your Cunning Action to make a {@skill Sleight of Hand} check, use your thieves' tools to open a lock, or take the {@action Use an Object} action.

entries.name: First Strike
entries: Also at 3rd level, you become practiced at hitting first and hitting hard. You have advantage on initiative rolls. You double your Special {@action Attack} damage against any creature that you beat on initiative in the first round.

entries.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: At 6th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice:
{@optfeature Escape the Skirmish|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Multiattack Defense|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Steel Will|Superheroic5E}

entries.name: Supreme Sneak
entries: Starting at 9th level, you have advantage on {@skill Stealth} checks.

entries.name: Infiltration Master
entries: When you reach 13th level, your ability to infiltrate both physical and electronic places excels. You now have proficiency with the disguise kit and forgery kit. If you spend a day researching a location or organization, you can establish a false identity and credentials that fool everyone, unless they are given an obvious reason to doubt your work. Anyone rolling to detect whether your identity or identification are forgeries rolls with disadvantage.

What's more, you can now hack computer networks and electronic security systems like a pro, leaving no traces. If you spend 1 minute accessing the relevant computer or security panel, you can hack any connected systems or devices except those with encryption or biometric security. When you hack or disable such security systems, you go undetected unless someone uses an action to make an {@skill Investigation} check that beats a DC equal to 8 + your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Operator's Reflexes
entries: When you reach 17th level, you have become adept at laying ambushes and quickly escaping danger. You can take two turns during the first round of any combat. You take your first turn at your normal initiative and your second turn at your initiative minus 10. You can't use this feature when you are surprised.

entries.name: Agent Division: Soldier
entries: Your area of specialization focuses on combat operations, sorties, and dealing massive damage when necessary.

entries.name: Special Attack: Aim
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you know how to aim your attacks at the more vulnerable areas of your foes. Once per turn, you can use your bonus action to deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack, if you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

If you continue to attack the same target and the target does not move out of its space, you may add your Special {@action Attack} damage on a hit against that enemy in every subsequent round of that combat. You may continue to do so until the enemy drops to zero HP, or you attack a different target, if you are not attacking with disadvantage.

You may also change which enemy you are aiming at by using a bonus action to assess a new target. Once you have done so, you may add your Special {@action Attack} damage to hits on that target if it does not leave its space.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Special {@action Attack} column of the Special Agent table.

entries.name: Additional Fighing Style
entries: When selecting your fighting style at 3rd level, you have the additional three options available to you to choose:
{@optfeature Great Weapon Fighting}
{@optfeature Grenadier|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Protection}

entries.name: Favored Technique
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain one of the following features of your choice:
{@optfeature Double Down|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature David vs Goliath|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Squad Breaker|Superheroic5E}

entries.name: Brutal Critical
entries: At 6th level, you can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack. This increases to three additional dice at 17th level.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: When you reach 9th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.
{@optfeature Volley|Superheroic5E}
{@optfeature Whirlwind Attack|Superheroic5E}

entries.name: Retaliation
entries: Starting at 13th level, when you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to make a melee attack against that creature.

entries.name: Combat Veteran
entries: Also at 13th level, you can choose a second option from the {@filter Fighting Style|optionalfeatures|feature type=fs:f;fs:b} class feature.

entries.name: Survivor
entries: At 17th level, you attain the pinnacle of resilience in battle. At the start of each of your turns, you regain HP equal to 5 + your Constitution modifier if you have no more than half of your HP left You don't gain this benefit if you have 0 HP.

entries.name: {@class Tech|Superheroic5E}
entries: Most heroes rely on enhanced or mutant genetics to gain superpowers. The Tech hero makes their own.

No matter how you might have gained the tech, you now have the gear to grant you awesome powers that allow you to stand shoulder to shoulder with other heroes. Of course, some would suggest that someone non-powered who chooses to fight against superpowered foes is foolhardy indeed, no matter the tech involved.

entries.name: Origin & Nature
entries: Tech heroes tend to be scientists or engineers, developing the technology that allows them to employ superpowers. Some Tech heroes are given the tech, however, perhaps by a corporation or even an alien force. And a devious few might have stolen the tech for their own purposes.
In any event, even to use and maintain such advanced technology requires a brilliant mind, so Tech heroes are usually highly intelligent.
Tech heroes can take many forms. Some wear suits of power armor, others cobble together odd gadgets, and still others wield high tech or alien weaponry.

entries.name: Creating a Tech
entries: Techs generally tend to develop their gear in one of three ways: as {@b power armor}, as makeshift, improvised {@b gadgets}, or as high-tech {@b weaponry}. When making a Tech hero, choose one of these three superpowered tech options. Your choice of superpowered tech determines what some of your powers will be, as well as granting you special benefits in certain circumstances.

entries.name: Class Features
entries: As a Tech superhero, you gain the following class features.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: {@bold Hit Dice}: {@dice 1d8} per level
{@bold Hit Points at 1st Level}: 18 + your Constitution modifier
{@bold Hit Points at Higher Levels}: {@dice 1d8} (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Martial Expert level after 1st
{@bold Saving Throws}: Dexterity and Intelligence

entries.name: Favored Tech
entries: When you become a Technological hero, you choose a particular approach to develop technology beyond what was previously thought possible, though the nature of that technology may differ from hero to hero. Select either the {@b power armor}, {@b gadgets}, or {@b weaponry} technologies, all of which grants the Superpowered Tech feature when chosen, as well as further abilities at 6th, 10th, 15th, and 20th levels. The Favored Tech options are described at the end of the Tech class description.

entries.name: Superpowered Tech
entries: Your affinity with technology is remarkable, bestowing you the ability to develop and use sophisticated tech to grant you the equivalent of superpowers, if you have access to your equipment. If you should be separated from all your technology, however, you do not have access to your superpowers.

entries.name: At Will Powers
entries: At 1st level, you know three at will powers from the Tech power list or the general power list. You learn additional at will powers at higher levels, as shown in the at will powers column of the Tech table.

entries.name: Leveled Power Slots
entries: The Tech table shows how many power slots are available for your leveled powers at each level. To use one of these powers, you must expend a slot of the power's level or higher. You regain all expended 1st through 8th level slots when you finish a short or long rest. You regain any expended 9th level power slots when you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Preparing Powers of 1st Level and Higher
entries: The Tech table shows how many power slots are available for your leveled powers at each level. To use one of these powers, you must expend a slot of the power's level or higher. You regain all expended 1st through 8th level slots when you finish a short or long rest. You regain any expended 9th level power slots when you complete a long rest.

For example, if you are a 3rd level Technological hero, you can use 1st level powers reflexively and have two 2nd level power slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared powers can include 6 powers of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination.

You can also change your prepared powers when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new selection of powers requires time spent with your technology and an appropriate set of tools. You must spend at least 1 minute per power level for each power on your list.

entries.name: Power Ability
entries: Intelligence is your power ability for your superpowers, since the strength of your powers relies on the brilliance and innovation you use to create and deploy advanced technologies. You use your Intelligence whenever a power refers to your power ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the save DC for a power you use and when making an attack roll with one.
{@b Power save DC =} 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
{@b Power attack modifier =} your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

entries.name: Power Ability
entries: By 2nd level, your time spent working with devices of all kinds pays off. You now have proficiency in both Science and Technology if you did not have it before. If you already have proficiency in one or both, you now have expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.

entries.name: Reflexive Powers
entries: Your skill with technology has allowed you to develop a virtually endless supply of energy for your lower-level superpowers.
Starting at 3rd level, 1st-level power use is now reflexive for you.
As your heroes level up, the levels at which they can use their powers reflexively also increases. [See "Reflexive Powers Use Example" sidebar on p. 25.]
Consult the chart above to see when heroes gain the ability to use higher-level powers reflexively.

entries.name: Handy
entries: When you reach 5th level, your skill with tools improves. You become proficient with two tools of your choice. When you roll a check with these tools, you add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Implanted Tech
entries: When you reach 9th level, you managed to create miniature versions of some of your simpler devices, which you can hide or implant in your body. This tech is undetectable by mundane scans. You can now use your at will powers even when you are separated from all your other tech, if your implanted tech is still with you.

entries.name: Field Modifications
entries: At 13th level, your ability to prepare your powers becomes much more efficient. Now you can change what powers you have prepared after you have completed a short or long rest. Preparing a new selection of powers requires time spent with your technology and an appropriate set of tools. You may select any number of powers that you had prepared after the previous rest and select only those you wish to exchange. You need spend only 1 minute per power you wish to swap out. You still must complete a long rest to regain spent slots, however.

entries.name: Backup Tech
entries: When you reach 18th level, you have gathered sufficient resources to ensure you always have a complete backup set of your favored tech. You also have implanted the trigger for a matter transferal device. As an action, you can activate the trigger and your backup set of superpowered tech arrives or materializes in a spot you choose within 5 feet of you. Only you can use this technology, however, as it is keyed specifically to you. Once you have used this feature, you cannot use it again for seven days.
Donning the new technology also renews your power slots, as if you had just completed a long rest.

entries.name: Favored Tech Options
entries: Describe your technology. Do you wear a shiny suit of chrome armor with repulsor blasters? Do you wield an alien energy glaive? Or perhaps you employ a swarm of nanites to create your superpowered effects? Work with your GM to determine the details.

entries.name: Favored Tech: Gadgets
entries: Some Tech heroes are consummate experimenters, creating different gadgets and devices regularly, to produce just the right effect needed at the time. Often, they build these gadgets in the field, improvising with whatever supplies are on hand. Indeed, the gadgeteer's devices could look bizarre and ridiculous, like a 50s era sci-fi ray gun, but they can also look mundane and unassuming, like a spy's watch that shoots lasers.

entries.name: Superpowered Gadgets
entries: When you choose this favored Tech option at 1st level, you gain the ability to construct gadgets that produce superpowered effects. Describe the current gadgets you employ and pick what powers they can create. You use your powers through these items, so without them you are powerless. You decide if they look outlandish or mundane; in either case, though, no one takes them seriously as a threat until you use them.
If you choose, you can wield superpowered gadgets without anyone thinking you are armed or bearing superpowered devices.

entries.name: Engineer
entries: You are a master at putting things together and taking them apart. You have advantage on Technology rolls

entries.name: Re-Spec Gadgets
entries: When you reach 6th level, you have gained enough of a mastery over your gadgets that you can now switch which powers your gadgets can produce very quickly. You can now change the powers of your gadgets in the field whenever you take a short rest. When you do so, you may choose different powers from the Tech or General lists.

entries.name: Reverse Engineered Tech
entries: At 10th level, you become able to reproduce superpowered effects that you have seen with your gadgets. When you prepare your powers, you can now select any 1st level powers that you have seen, as if they were on the Tech list.

entries.name: Hot Swapping
entries: When you reach 15th level, you become able to swap out what effects your gadgets produce on the fly. With 1 uninterrupted minute with your gadgets, you can change which powers your gadgets produce. When you do so, you may choose different powers from the Tech or General lists.

entries.name: Ultimate Versatility
entries: By 20th level, you have seen many other superpowers on display and performed their complete analysis, allowing you to reproduce virtually any low-level power you have seen. When you prepare your powers, you can now select any 1st-3rd level powers that you have seen, as if they were on the Tech list.

entries.name: Favored Tech: Power Armor
entries: A Tech who specializes in power armor creates a set of high-tech armor that provides protection as well as the ability to use superpowers. This power armor is unique to the Tech hero and allows them to perform remarkable heroic feats.

entries.name: Power Suit
entries: When you choose the Power Armor favored Tech option, you fabricate or acquire a set of armor that provides some measure of protection, as well as provides you the ability to create superpowered effects. Without this armor, however, you are powerless.
Choose whether your power armor is light, medium, or heavy. You are proficient in this armor.

entries.name: Power Suit Options
entries: Describe your armor. What does it look like? Work with your GM to determine how your power armor works.

entries.name: Enhanced Armor
entries: At 6th level, you upgrade your power armor. You gain +1 to your armor’s AC.

entries.name: Hotfix
entries: When you reach 10th level, you become more adept at adjusting your power armor in response to your environment. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to that type of damage, including the triggering instance of damage. You retain this resistance until you complete a short or long rest when the resistance ends. Once you have used this power, you also cannot use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: New Model
entries: At 15th level, you develop new technology that transforms your power armor. When wearing your power armor, you now have a flying speed of 60 feet. What's more, when wearing your power armor, you now have {@sense Darkvision} out to 120 feet.

entries.name: Final Form
entries: When you reach 20th level, you develop your power armor into its final form. You have resistance to all damage except psychic damage.

entries.name: Favored Tech: Weaponry
entries: Some Tech heroes carry high-tech weapons and devices, with which they wield superpowers. Perhaps you found a laser sword that cuts through steel; or built a multipurpose tool that you wear on your arm that can project force, a blade, or a shield; or were gifted an alien ring that lets you project hard light. Whatever you carry, you have one or a set of special devices that grant you superpowers.

entries.name: Superpowered Weaponry
entries: When you choose this favored tech option at 1st level, you gain a high-tech weapon or device of your choice. Describe the item and work with your GM to determine its details. When you use your powers, you channel energy from your high-tech weapon to create a wide variety of superpowered effects, though without it you are powerless. Thanks to the potency of your weapon, you have a +2 on your attack and damage rolls.

entries.name: Channel Energy
entries: When you reach 6th level, you develop the ability to channel energy from your environment into your high-tech weaponry and devices. When you hit a creature with a power attack, you can use your reaction to expend one power slot to deal additional damage to the target. The extra damage is {@dice 1d8} force for a 1st-level slot plus {@dice 1d8} for each additional power level higher than 1st.

entries.name: Sentient Weaponry
entries: At 10th level, your high-tech weapon or weapons awaken and gain a life of their own, though they are dedicated to serving and protecting you.

Your high-tech weapons communicate telepathically with you and can speak, read, and understand all the languages that you can. Your weapons have an Intelligence score of 18, a Wisdom of 14, and a Charisma of 12, as well as hearing and {@sense Darkvision} out to 120 feet.
Their added sentience makes your weaponry even more deadly in combat. You now have a +3 on your attack and damage rolls with them.

entries.name: Potent Attack
entries: When you reach 15th level, your high-tech weapons become even more powerful. Your superpowered attacks now ignore damage resistance.

entries.name: Lethal Weapons
entries: By 20th level, your weaponry is more deadly than ever. You score a critical hit with your weapon attacks and powers on an 18-20.

The Piercing Agony of Knowing Oneself, This Fire of Awareness Never Dims. Acutely Pained By How Close I am to Having the Power I Need But Lack. Time Has Collapsed On Itself Making These... Days... Unbearable in the Waiting.

entries.name: {@class Vitalist|Superheroic5E}
entries: Vitalist heroes hold sway over some aspect of the natural world. Some Vitalists call upon legions of animals to do their bidding, while others manifest animal traits themselves. Still others command plant life, channeling plant toxins or other properties.

Some Vitalist heroes take on the appearance of their natural domains, coming to resemble an animal or something botanical in nature. Others, however, only present those qualities when they wish, perhaps transforming into a mundane looking human at times. Still others never change their bodies at all, instead commanding the natural world around them to serve.

entries.name: Origin & Nature
entries: Some Vitalist heroes are born into their powers, as a mutation or an ancient genetic heritage. Perhaps you encountered a natural spirit or deity who bestowed upon you these powers, appointing you as warden and protector of nature. Or maybe you became what you are through experimentation or other scientific intervention. Regardless, you now command and commune with nature like no other hero can.

entries.name: Creating an Vitalist
entries: Vitalists may be connected to the entirety of the natural world, holding some sway over plants and animals, but each Vitalist hero has a strength. When making a Vitalist hero, choose a natural domain: {@b animals} or {@b plants}. Your choice of domain determines what some of your superpowers are, as well as grants special benefits in certain circumstances.

entries.name: Class Features
entries: As an Vitalist superhero, you gain the following class features.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: {@bold Hit Dice}: {@dice 1d10} per level
{@bold Hit Points at 1st Level}: 20 + your Constitution modifier
{@bold Hit Points at Higher Levels}: {@dice 1d10} (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per Mentalist level after 1st
{@bold Saving Throws}: Constitution and Wisdom

entries.name: Vital Power
entries: As a conduit for the vital forces of nature, you gain superpowers.

entries.name: At Will Powers
entries: At 1st level, you know two at will powers from the Vitalist power list or the General power list. You learn additional at will powers at higher levels, as shown in the at will powers column of the Vitalist table.

entries.name: Powers Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level powers of your choice from the Vitalist or General power lists.
The "Leveled Powers Known" column of the Vitalist table shows when you learn additional powers of your choice. Each of these powers must be of a level for which you have slots.

For example, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new power of 1st or 2nd level. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the powers you know and replace it with another power from the Vitalist or General lists, which also must be of a level for which you have slots, bringing the total number of powers you know to five.

entries.name: Leveled Power Slots
entries: The Vitalist table shows how many power slots you must use your powers at each level. To use one of these powers, you must expend a slot of the power's level or higher. You regain all expended 1st through 8th level slots when you finish a short or long rest. You regain any expended 9th level power slots when you complete a long rest.

Once you reach certain levels, you gain the ability to use powers at certain levels reflexively. Once you do so, you no longer have slots at those levels and can use powers at those levels at will, as if you had an endless number of power slots available.

entries.name: Power Ability
entries: Wisdom is your power ability for your superpowers since the potency of your powers derives from your intuitive connection to the natural world and its denizens. You use your Wisdom whenever a power refers to your power ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the save DC for a power you use and when making an attack roll with one.
{@b Power save DC =} 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
{@b Power attack modifier =} your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

entries.name: Natural Domain
entries: You gain your superpowers from the power of the natural world. Choose a natural domain that captures the ways in which you use your powers: {@b animal} or {@b plant}. Your choice grants you domain powers and other features when you choose it at 1st level. It also grants you additional ways to use Channel {@skill Nature} when you gain that feature at 2nd level, and additional benefits at 6th, 13th, and 20th levels.

entries.name: Domain Powers
entries: Each domain has a list of powers—its domain powers—that you gain at the Vitalist levels noted in the domain description. Once you gain a domain power, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of powers you can prepare each day.
If you have a domain power that doesn't appear on the Vitalist power list, the power is nonetheless a Vitalist power for you.

entries.name: Channel Nature
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to channel natural energy directly from the biosphere, using that energy to fuel superpowered effects. You start with two such effects: Wild Rapport and an effect determined by your domain. Some domains grant you additional effects as you advance in levels, as noted in the domain description.
When you use your Channel {@skill Nature}, you choose which effect to create. You must then finish a short or long rest to use your Channel {@skill Nature} again.
Some Channel {@skill Nature} effects require saves. When you use such an effect from this class, the DC equals your Vitalist power save DC.

Beginning at 6th level, you can use your Channel {@skill Nature} twice between rests, and beginning at 18th level, you can use it three times between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

entries.name: Channel Nature: Wild Repport
entries: As an action, you attune yourself to the essence of nature around you and call upon it to serve. Perhaps you release animal pheromones or a botanical scent. Every living humanoid, beast, plant, or monstrosity within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom save. If the creature fails its save, it is {@condition charmed} by you for 1 minute or until it takes any damage.

A {@condition charmed} creature can't attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful abilities or magical effects and the charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature. Creatures with an Intelligence of 4 or higher may make another Wisdom save at the end of each of their turns. On a success, they are no longer {@condition charmed} by you. When the effect ends, the creature knows it was {@condition charmed} by you.

entries.name: Natural Affinity
entries: Also at 2nd level, you become more adept at understanding and interacting with flora and fauna. You gain proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} and {@skill Survival} if you did not have one or both already. If you did, you gain expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.

entries.name: Reflexive Powers
entries: Starting at 3rd level, 1st-level power use is now reflexive for you. This means that you have a limitless supply of 1st-level power slots. If you wish to use abilities at higher level, however, you must expend a higher-level slot as normal.
As your heroes level up, the levels at which they can use their powers reflexively also increases. [See "Reflexive Powers: An Example" sidebar on p. 25 in Chapter 3.]
Consult the chart above to see when heroes gain the ability to use higher-level powers reflexively.

entries.name: Nature's Ally
entries: When you reach 5th level, your link to the natural world deepens, allowing you to navigate natural environments with ease.

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow you or your group's travel.
Your group can't become lost except by supernatural means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

entries.name: Vital Strike
entries: When you reach 9th level, you gain the ability to infuse your attacks with vital energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with an attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} poison damage to the target. When you reach 18th level, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d8}.

entries.name: Improved Wild Rapport
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you use the Wild Rapport Channel {@skill Nature} ability, any creature in range of a challenge rating below a certain threshold automatically fails its first save against the effect. The threshold by level is shown in the Improved Wild Rapport table.

entries.name: Toxin Tolerance
entries: At 15th level, your connection to the natural world has inured you to most toxins and caustic substances it produces. You are immune to acid and poison damage, as well as disease.

entries.name: Animal Domain
entries: The animal domain focuses on the beasts of land, air, and sea, both large and small. Vitalists who claim this domain form a bond with all beasts, one that allows you to communicate with, command, and become a wild animal.

entries.name: Animal Domain Powers
entries: Those whose natural domain is animals know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Animal Companion
entries: When you choose the animal domain at 1st level, you gain an animal companion with which you form a bond.
Select a beast of CR 1 or lower. The creature has its normal stats, with the following changes:

items: Add your proficiency bonus to all its ability scores and adjust its HP, skills, attacks, and damage accordingly.
Give the animal companion the maximum number of HP it can have with its current hit dice.

entries: When you gain a Vitalist level, your animal companion levels up as well. Add the average of the beast's hit die, add any Constitution modifier, and then add this sum to its HP. If your proficiency bonus increases when you level up, be sure to add the increase to the animal's ability scores and adjust the beast's stats accordingly.

entries.name: An Example Animal Companion
entries: For her animal companion, Ivy chooses a black panther. Her proficiency bonus is +2, so she adds +2 to each of the panther's ability scores. She adjusts the panther's stats accordingly, raising its attack from +4 to +5, for example. She then changes its HP from 13 ({@dice 3d8}) to 27 ({@dice 3d8 + 3}). When the panther levels up, Ivy takes the maximum for the panther's hit die of {@dice d8}, and adds the panther's Constitution bonus of +1, raising the panther's total HP to 36. When Ivy's proficiency bonus goes up to +3, she increases the bonus to the panther's ability scores from +2 to +3 and adjusts the affected stats as well. Her panther is becoming truly formidable!

As a bonus action while your animal companion can see and hear you, you can issue verbal commands to your companion that it will try its best to follow. You can command your companion to move somewhere, as well as to perform one action: attack a foe you specify, defend, interact with an object to the extent it is capable, or hide. Your companion continues to perform that action until they can no longer do so, or you issue a new command.

If your companion drops to zero HP, it is {@condition incapacitated}, but does not die. It reawakens at the end of combat with 1 HP. If your companion does die or is lost, you can summon a replacement that appears in 24 hours. Thanks to the supernatural bonds you have formed with your companion, a part of its essence remains with you. Thus, when the replacement beast arrives, it inherits the mind and experiences of your original companion in the new body. The replacement companion has the same stats that the original did when it died.

entries.name: Channel Nature: Wild Shape
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel {@skill Nature} to assume the shape of a beast that you have seen alive and in person before.

Your Vitalist level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. At 2nd level, for example, you can transform into any beast that has a challenge rating of 1 or lower that doesn't have a flying speed.

As you rise in Vitalist levels, you can assume more shapes. At 6th level and above, you can assume the shape of living beasts you have seen with a flying speed. And 10th level and up, you need only have seen photos of the beast to assume its shape, though it must have been a real, existing creature at one time.

You can stay in a beast shape for a number of hours equal to half your Vitalist level (rounded down). You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another use of this feature. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall {@condition unconscious}, drop to 0 HP, or die.
While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all your skill and save proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature's bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can't use them.

When you transform, you assume the beast's HP and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of HP you had before you transformed. However, if you revert because of dropping to 0 HP, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in animal form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. If the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 HP, you aren't knocked {@condition unconscious}.

You can't use powers, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn't break your {@status concentration} on a power you've already used, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a power, such as {@spell call lightning}, that you've already used.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class, ancestry, culture, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as {@sense darkvision}, unless your new form also has that sense.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the GM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature's shape and size. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

entries.name: Beast Friend
entries: At 6th level, beasts are naturally friendly to you. Every beast within 10 feet of you acts as if you had used the {@spell animal friendship} power and it had failed its save. The effect lingers for the duration even if the beast moves away from you afterwards.

entries.name: Animal Instict
entries: When you reach 10th level, you have developed keen senses and an instinctive awareness of danger. You now have advantage on {@skill Perception} checks, your Passive {@skill Perception} increases by 5, and you have advantage on initiative rolls.

entries.name: Domain Mastery
entries: When you reach 13th level, you gain even greater mastery over your animal domain powers. You can now use any power listed in the {@b Animal Domain Powers} table as a bonus action.

entries.name: Beast Powers
entries: Beginning at 20th level, you can use your Vitalist powers in any shape you assume using {@b Wild Shape} and can speak in your normal voice, even if the beast into which you have transformed cannot normally do so.

entries.name: Plant Domain
entries: Vitalists who claim the plant domain have a deep connection to all things botanical, as well as the overall natural environment, or ecosystem, around them. These Vitalists can channel powers and abilities borrowed from the natural world, as well as call upon and manipulate plants.

entries.name: Plant Domain Powers
entries: Those whose natural domain is plants know the following powers, which do not count toward their total number of powers known.

entries.name: Plant Domain Powers
entries: When you choose the plant natural domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency in Science, if you do not already have it. If you do have it, you instead gain expertise. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency. You roll with advantage on any Science check concerning plants.

entries.name: Green Thumb
entries: Also at 1st level, you become more capable with powers that invoke plants or the natural environment around you. You may use any power for which you have slots on the plant domain powers table as a bonus action.

entries.name: Channel Nature: Spore Cloud
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel {@skill Nature} to expel a cloud of spores from your body. The cloud fills a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on you. And remains for 1 minute.

You can choose how the spores affect the creatures currently in the spore cloud, either healing or harming them. If you choose to heal a creature in the spore cloud, including yourself, they receive temporary HP equal to your Wisdom modifier. If you choose to harm them, they must make a Constitution save or take {@damage 2d8} poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. On a successful save, the creature is immune to this spore cloud for its duration.
The spore cloud lasts for one minute, until you become {@condition incapacitated} or die, or if you choose to end the effect. The spore cloud follows you when you move.
