Each round after you create it until it ends, you can use a bonus action to refresh the spore cloud. When you do so, you can again elect to heal or harm each creature within the cloud, as before.
When you reach 13th level, the radius of your spore cloud increases to 30 feet and the damage to {@dice 3d8}.

entries.name: Heightening Summoning
entries: When you reach 6th level, you gain further skill with manipulating plants. When you conjure forth plants or insects with the entangle, spike growth, insect plague, or wall of thorns powers, you can create pockets of relative safety within the effects of your powers. When you use a power that affects other visible creatures, you can choose a number of them equal to 1 + the power's level. The chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saves against the power, and they take no damage if they would normally take half damage on a successful save.
What's more, when you use one of these powers, you may roll damage twice and use the higher number.

entries.name: Land's Stride
entries: Also at 6th level, moving through difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. You can also pass through plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard.
In addition, you have advantage on saves against plants that are created by superpowers or manipulated to impede movement, such as those created by the entangle power.

entries.name: Hardy
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can draw life force from the biosphere when in dire need. The first time you would drop to 0 HP because of taking damage, you instead drop to 1 HP, and the protection ends. If you are subjected to an effect that would kill you instantaneously without dealing damage, that effect is instead negated against the target, and the effect ends. Once the protective effect ends, it does not return until you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Vital Sense
entries: At 13th level, you attune to the ecosystem around you at a subconscious level. You can sense any living being of size Tiny or larger that is within 30 feet of you, even if it is hidden, {@condition invisible}, or behind total cover.

entries.name: Biosphere Communion
entries: At 20th level, your communion with the biosphere is complete. If you die, you can choose to be reborn 7 days later. A large tree trunk or other plant life splits open at a location you choose on the same planet, and you awaken within, without any of your equipment.

This feature closes all wounds, neutralizes any poison, cures all diseases, and lifts any curses affecting you when you died. It replaces damaged or missing organs and limbs and can even provide a new body if your original no longer exists. The new body is identical to a healthy version of the one you had before you died.
If you are in outer space and there is no botanical life or available ecosystem within a thousand miles, this feature does not function.
These Insignificant Peons in This Dirty City By The Water. I Took My Book Back! Again Chained To Me As It Should Always Have Been, It Comforts Me. I Continue To Expand...

data.name: Background & Personality
entries: Your superhero is almost finished! All that remains is to choose a background and describe your hero's personality and appearance. This chapter also provides a list of Feats you can take at certain levels, as listed in your hero class table.

entries.name: {@background Athlete|Superheroic5E}
entries: Either for fun or profit, your life circles around athletics. Perhaps you are a martial arts instructor or an aspiring professional baseball player. Or maybe you simply spend all your time working out, be it Tae Kwon Do, running, or rugby. Whatever the case may be, you participate in the organizations that govern and promote your chosen activities for much of your life.

entries.name: {@background Con Artist|Superheroic5E}
entries: You make your living telling stories that people want to hear—stories that end with you relieving them of some of their money. It's a skill you've developed over time and built through practiced lies, faked documents, and the occasional picked pocket. You sometimes even must become someone else entirely to escape. Your chosen profession is not popular with the police, who do not take kindly to your practices.

entries.name: {@background Corporate Drone|Superheroic5E}
entries: The rich and powerful believe it is their work alone that built their wealth, but you know better. Having worked among the cubicles at one of the world's largest corporations, you know how things work and how to get things done. Your name might not have wealth and prestige attached like those of the CEOs, but you know how to cut through bureaucracy when necessary—and other office plebs are more likely to help you out. Work with your GM to determine which corporation you work for or once worked for and whether you still have pull in the office.

entries.name: {@background Criminal|Superheroic5E}
entries: You make your living doing shady work. Perhaps you steal or serve as muscle for other crooks. Some of the most common criminal jobs recently have been credit card skimming and identity theft—lucrative, but dangerous. Whatever you preferred crime, you have spent enough time among the seedier folks in the city to pick up several useful skills. Work with your GM to determine what you preferred job is. Options include burglar, high tech thief, pickpocket, or thug.

entries.name: {@background Entertainer|Superheroic5E}
entries: You dance, sing, act, joke, or otherwise entertain people as a living. Perhaps you were brought up in an entertaining family. Possibly it is a path you fell into or chose at some point. Regardless, you now have at least one act that reliably drums up some coin.
Work with your GM to imagine at least one performance you have in your repertoire. Whatever you choose, make sure you can describe a bit of what it looks like when you perform.

entries.name: {@background Explorer|Superheroic5E}
entries: Whether you come from another world or simply wish to find the secret places of your own, you spend your time going where others have not. Some explorers plumb the depths of the ocean or sail the most remote seas; still other travel the stars, or even the stream of time, looking for discovery.
Work with your GM to determine what you like to explore and why you do so; are you looking for something in particular, or is it simply novel experiences you seek?

entries.name: {@background Indigent|Superheroic5E}
entries: The city may be a bustling metropolis filled with workers and wealth, but it also has a massive number of poor and itinerant people. You were one such person, having lived for at least a few years on the streets and in the alleys of the lower-origin areas among the homeless. You may have panhandled here and there, or perhaps you sung or did a simple dance on a street corner until the police would run you off. Maybe you scavenged in others' dumpsters for food and odd trinkets to pawn. Some of your associates would resort to petty theft

If you like, you may also choose an area of the city you frequented when you were down on your luck. Work with your GM to decide how you ended up indigent and whether you've pulled yourself out of it or not. If so, how?
Did someone help you?

entries.name: {@background Journalist|Superheroic5E}
entries: You work issue to issue, selling your photos or stories as you can, submitting it to news agencies or tabloids. Perhaps you had some formal training in journalism school, but it is just as likely that you are mostly self-taught. Maybe you have some articles or photos in a local rag or college student paper. Nevertheless, you have a real and useful skill which you can use to support yourself, as well as a loose network of fellow members of your craft Work with your GM to determine your specific relationship to various news or photography outlets and perhaps even describe a few of your works.

entries.name: {@background Laborer|Superheroic5E}
entries: You make your living by the sweat of your brow and through your exertions, the city works. Indeed, years of manual labor have toughened you up and made you strong. You may be a stevedore, hired to unload container ships, or a factory worker on an assembly line. Or perhaps, rather than working the line at the factory, you work in an auto body shop, or as a mechanic in a garage. There's no job too dirty; if it needs doing, you can do it.

One advantage of this line of work is that it brings you in contact with other laborers who have similar experiences. These like-minded groups of laborers are often in unions or, at least, share a sense of mutual aid to support one another. Work with your GM to determine whether you belong to a union or one of these informal communities. Where is it? Is it politically active?

entries.name: {@background Medical Worker|Superheroic5E}
entries: You work in the medical field, as a nurse, doctor, or assistant. Perhaps you went to nursing school and received your LPN or RN. There you learned how to bandage wounds, set bones, and administer medication, among other things. You also know your way around a pharmacy or hospital. Though you lack the scientific expertise and advanced training of the medical doctor, your skills can be very useful in the field. Work with your GM to determine the details of your training and former employment.

entries.name: {@background Military Trained|Superheroic5E}
entries: You served in the army, or perhaps on a police force, and have likely seen combat as well. Your experience has marked you and those you served alongside will forever be family.

Work with your GM to determine where you served and in what capacity. Where you in the American armed forces? Local police force? Foreign military? CIA strike team? Next, determine what relationship, if any, you still have to your old organization and your former soldiersin-arms. Perhaps you still maintain relations with a few of them.

entries.name: {@background Monastic|Superheroic5E}
entries: You were raised or have spent a considerable amount of time in a monastery, enclave, commune, or other isolated and insular community. Perhaps the people there were united by a common ideology; regardless, you grew to know their ways very well.

Work with your GM to determine the nature of your former community. Was it a religious community, like a monastery? Or a political one instead? Was it intentionally low tech? Or was it a scholarly enclave? Next, determine what relationship, if any, you still have to your old community and its members. Perhaps you still maintain relations with a few of them.

entries.name: {@background Pilot|Superheroic5E}
entries: You spent several years as a pilot, of a commercial airline or, perhaps, a cruise ship. Your years in the sky or at sea have given you ample experience with the travel industry, as well as skill piloting a variety of commercial vessels and vehicles. You may even have served in the Air Force or Navy in the past, but you've been working in the commercial industry for a while now. Indeed, unlikely as it might be, you may even have hoped to train as an astronaut.
Choose what vehicles you pilot and how you gained this experience.

entries.name: {@background Service Industry Worker|Superheroic5E}
entries: The most common form of employment, by far, is in the service industry, and you are among them. Whether you work in food service—front or back of the house—or in retail or similar, your work ultimately brings you into contact with customers, for better or worse. The good news is you have skills that make it easy for you to find work. The bad news is most of the jobs you can find don't pay very well.

Choose what area of service you worked in. Some examples are kitchen staff, wait staff, housekeeping, lawn care, IT, tourism, entertainment, sales, consulting, etc. Then work with your GM to determine where you worked. Did you leave under good circumstances or bad? The relationship with your former employer(s) may end up being important as the story unfolds!

entries.name: {@background Scientist|Superheroic5E}
entries: Isaac Newton. Marie Curie. Neil deGrasse Tyson. These figures inspire you in your relentless search for the truth about the natural world. You employ experimental methods, collecting observations, and sharing your findings with your scientific community, be it at a local university, online group, or publishing in scientific journals.

Choose your preferred area of scientific pursuit. Perhaps you study genetics, trying to discover the source of the superpowers a lucky few heroes develop. Or you study materials science, producing substances that can serve as lightweight, impenetrable armor for tomorrow's Technological heroes. Whatever your area, you conduct your experiments in a lab. Work with your GM to determine where it is and what it might contain. Is it functional? Exploded? Dangerous? Your GM may give you opportunities to visit it and conduct an experiment.

entries.name: {@background Student or Scholar|Superheroic5E}
entries: You live the life of the mind. Probably, you have an advanced degree, but you might be an autodidact, however, in which case your erudition is especially impressive. Whatever its source, your knowledge is expansive and impressive, though, you focus on a particular area of study. Work with your GM to determine what your focus is and where you conduct your studies. Perhaps you delve into dusty tomes and archives to uncover the truth about history, in which case you might spend time in government buildings examining old documents. Or maybe you study ancient languages and translate Homer or Horace, while holing up at your old university. Or maybe you study the works of the great philosophers, in which case you might frequent symposiums and discuss your ideas with other scholars. You might even engage in your scholarly exchanges entirely in writing, submitting essays to prestigious journals. Wherever you work, you have built special relationships with other like-minded folks with which you share your passions. Normal folks might call you an egghead, however.

entries.name: {@background Survivalist|Superheroic5E}
entries: You grew up well outside of the city. Your people work the land and have for generations. Indeed, the way the elders in your community tell it, you are the land. You likely worked a particular crop or bred a domesticated animal or two and know them best, but your agrarian life taught you how to grow a variety of crops, as well as raise other forms of livestock.

Something led you to leave your quiet rural life behind, however, and come to the city. Was it when you got your powers? What happened? Work with your GM to imagine a story that brings you from there to where you are now. Be sure to include conflict in the tale, so that the GM might invoke it at a later moment in the story!

entries.name: {@background Wealthy Aristocrat|Superheroic5E}
entries: Some say you had an easy upbringing. In one sense, of course you did—the most privileged imaginable, really. Even so, satisfying your distant and perfectionist parents wasn't easy, to say the least. You learned, though, how to maneuver among the rich and powerful elite, which turns out to be a useful life skill after all. Work with your GM to determine if your parents are still around, whether you are the young new CEO of a major corporation, or just a celebrity socialite.

entries.name: {@background Custom Background|Superheroic5E}
entries: Maybe the list of provided backgrounds doesn't quite capture what your character's been up to, you can create one tailor-made instead. What might your hero have been doing before becoming a superhero? Where were they living? What was their job, if any? If you choose this background, describe your life before superheroics. Work with your GM to make it interesting and fun.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: One way to begin to flesh out your hero is to describe their appearance. What would people notice upon first meeting them? This description can include basic descriptions like height and weight, eye color, hair color and style, and skin tone. It can also include more holistic judgements, like their gender presentation and their sense of style.

Furthermore, you should decide how your hero presents themselves both when they are acting as a superhero in public and when they are living their mundane life. Do they have a secret identity? Or are they always just their superheroic selves, even when at home?

Ideally, you'll form a mental image of your hero, perhaps writing a description that others can read or hear to get the idea. You might even track down or commission some art that you think captures your hero as well.

entries.name: Backstory
entries: It isn't necessary, but you may enjoy thinking about the history of your superhero as well, to get to know them more and to better enjoy roleplaying them.

In addition to your heroic cornerstone and vulnerability, where did you grow up? Do you have siblings? What is your relationship to the family or friends? Do you have political, religious, or philosophical opinions that might color how you interact with the world around you? If you developed their powers at a certain point in your life, how did that change impact you? What attitude do you have toward your powers? Now that you have and use them in superheroic ways, what is your attitude toward that role? Is it an obligation? Something you do for fun? Out of moral principle? For money?
Finally, you may wish to think about what kind of personality your hero might have. Are you funny? Serious? Rational? Erratic?
Answering some of these questions can help you to complete your character concept and can make the game a richer experience.

entries.name: Feats
entries: A feat represents a talent or an area of expertise that gives a character special capabilities. It embodies training, experience, and abilities beyond what a class provides.

At certain levels, your class gives you the Ability Score Improvement or Feat feature. You can take a feat of your choice, or you can instead choose whether to increase your ability scores by 2 points, assigning one each to two different abilities or two to one ability. You can take each feat only once unless the feat's description says otherwise.

Some feats list prerequisites that should be met before taking the feat, though players may wish to work with their GM to see if a particular feat might be appropriate even if your hero doesn't meet the prerequisites. Many feats list associated classes and subclasses to help players to choose; these are not requirements for taking the feat, however.

data.name: Equipment
entries: In your superheroic adventures, you may play as, or encounter, agents, Martial Experts, law enforcement officers, military personnel, criminals, or gangsters, any of which might carry a weapon. As the heroes slug it out with villains across the city, they may engage in speeding car chases and shoot-outs or, at higher levels, military grade artillery and more.
This chapter provides the rules for weapons, armor, vehicles, equipment, and tool kits, as well as information on living expenses.

Most superheroic adventures and stories don't focus much on money. In discussion with the group, the GM may decide not to worry about questions of how the heroes pay their rent or afford their weapons and ammunition. If you wish to include such matters in your game, however, this chapter provides not only fun gear, but costs and weights as well.

An unskilled worker can expect to make roughly $50 for a day of work, or $250 a week, whereas a skilled worker can make $150/day, or $750/week. The prices for items in S5E are included in the weapons, equipment, and tools lists below.

entries.name: Armor
entries: When you play a game set in something close to the modern world, most medieval or ancient styles of armor are obsolete. Even so, some armors are still available and can be of great use for a certain kind of hero.

entries.name: Superhero Costumes
entries: At 1st level, your heroes probably have costumes cobbled together from everyday items: ski masks, balaclavas, motorcycle helmets, hockey masks, homemade insignias sewn into street clothes, and so on.

Once the heroes reach higher levels, however, they might wish to acquire more official costumes. Your world may even have a superhero costume designer or provider; perhaps there is a fashion maven who delights in making specialty wear for the discerning hero, or maybe the heroes know a back-alley blacksmith who fashions brutal armor for vigilantes. Either way, your heroes may wish to acquire costumes that also function as armor. Any of the armor options below can be designed and decorated to function as armor but appear as a costume. For a classic superheroic look that is nevertheless protective, opt for the futuristic fabrics option, if your GM allows it.

At the highest levels, heroes can choose to wear specialized costumes that can withstand the massive destructive power they deal out and receive. With GM approval, heroes may elect to wear one of the heavier futuristic armor options as an especially resilient, custom designed costume that can withstand the most intense forms of damage, all while looking stylish, iconic, or menacing, as the heroes prefer.

entries.name: The Armor Table
entries: The Armor table collects the most commonly available types of armor found in the game and separates them into three categories: {@b light armor, medium armor, and heavy armor}. Some combatants also supplement their armor with a shield. The Armor table shows the cost, weight, and other properties of the common types of armor worn in modern fantasy gaming worlds.

entries.name: Armor Proficiency.
entries: Anyone can put on a Kevlar vest or pick up a riot shield. Only those proficient in the armor's use know how to wear it effectively, however. Your class gives you proficiency with certain types of armor. If you wear armor that you lack proficiency with, you have disadvantage on any ability check, save, or attack roll that involves Strength or Dexterity

entries.name: Armor Class (AC).
entries: Armor protects its wearer from attacks. The armor (and shield) you wear determines your base Armor Class

entries.name: Heavy Armor.
entries: Heavier armor interferes with the wearer's ability to move quickly, stealthily, and freely. If the Armor table shows "Str 13" or "Str 15" in the Strength column for an armor type, the armor reduces the wearer's speed by 10 feet unless the wearer has a Strength score equal to or higher than the listed score.

entries.name: Stealth
entries: If the Armor table shows "Disadvantage" in the {@skill Stealth} column, the wearer has disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks.

entries.name: Superheroes and Armor
entries: Unlike fantasy adventurers, superheroes do not tend to wear armor regularly, instead opting for relatively lightweight costumes. Indeed, mundane armor is fairly ineffective for superheroes; they can usually sustain more damage than any basic piece of armor could endure. Futuristic and advanced armors can be lifesavers, however, which is why superheroes rarely wear armor unless it is top of the line, advanced tech, or incredibly heavy duty armor. Note that the futuristic armors allow heroes to add their proficiency bonus to their AC, just as they do when they are unarmored.

entries.name: Light Armor
entries: Made from supple and thin materials, light armor favors agile heroes since it offers some protection without sacrificing mobility. If you wear light armor, you add your Dexterity modifier to the base number from your armor type to determine your Armor Class.

entries.name: {@item Tactical Streetwear|Superheroic5E}.
entries: Tactical streetwear is cutting edge, high fashion clothing that resembles everyday streetwear, but is made with high tech fabrics and designs, inspired by military and sports applications. These materials provide some modest protection, but do not look like armor at all. (4 lb., $100)

entries.name: {@item Leather|Superheroic5E}
entries: Leather jackets and pants provide some protection from harm and are a necessity when riding motorcycles, for example. As such, they are a common sight on the street and draw no special attention. (8 lb., $50)

entries.name: {@item Reinforced Leather|Superheroic5E}
entries: Worn by stuntmen and competitive motorcyclists, these leathers are reinforced in the torso, shoulders, hips, elbows, and knees. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials. Such outfits are not uncommon on the street, as some casual motorcyclists wear them, and they are not much bulkier than plain leather. (12 lb., $150)

entries.name: {@item Studded Leather|Superheroic5E}
entries: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes. Outside of leather bars or classic metal shows, however, such apparel is unusual. (15 lb., $75)

entries.name: {@item Futuristic Fabrics|Superheroic5E}
entries: Composed of advanced materials, this armor resembles a quasi-metallic fabric that is nevertheless pliable and form-fitting. It can be worn beneath normal clothing and is nearly undetectable when done so. It is light-weight and remarkably resistant to bullets and blades alike. It could also serve as an advanced material with which to make a superhero costume. (5 lb., $1,000)

entries.name: Medium Armor
entries: Medium armor offers more protection than light armor, but it also impairs movement more. If you wear medium armor, you add your Dexterity modifier, to a maximum of +2, to the base number from your armor type to determine your Armor Class.

entries.name: Flak Jacket
entries: This cloth vest features hard ballistic plates of metal or ceramic sewn into its fabric. These bulky vests were developed during World War 2 and are no longer standard issue. Wearing one in public would draw concerned looks. (25 lb., $50)

entries.name: Kevlar Vest.
entries: Kevlar is a fabric of overlapping layers of a high tensile strength fiber. Thanks to this, these soft, laminated vests are lighter weight than earlier ballistic vests, thus allowing more freedom of movement, yet they do a better job stopping small caliber firearms. These are standard issue for most law enforcement officers, as well as some security guards. They can be worn under coats and jackets without drawing attention. (15 lb., $200)

entries.name: Reinforced Kevlar.
entries: Like their predecessors, these vests are made of a laminated nylon and Kevlar, but with the addition of small ceramic inserts in key locations on the torso, adding only a small amount of weight, yet being able to stop larger caliber weapons and some shrapnel. The inserted plates mean that this vest is hard and bulkier than plain Kevlar, however. Riot police might wear armor like this. As such, someone wearing it in public would cause concern. (25 lb., $350)

entries.name: Modular Tactical Vest.
entries: This modern development in personal armor weighs a more than a reinforced Kevlar vest, though it can stop even higher caliber rounds and shrapnel. It is a harder, bulkier armor. Some armed forces might wear armor like this in a combat zone. (30 lb., $1000)

entries.name: Futuristic Tactical Armor.
entries: This suit of battle armor uses lab manufactured ceramisteel plates inlaid in a suit of advanced polymer fabrics. It appears much like the modular tactical vest of the 21st century, but the material is much lighter and more flexible, and the plates are given a personalized molding to afford more complete coverage. It could also serve as an advanced material with which to make a superhero costume. (35 lb., $10,000)
{@i Note: unless used to make a durable superhero costume, this item is only intended for games with science fiction or superadvanced technology, unless the GM decides otherwise.}

entries.name: Heavy Armor
entries: Of all the armor categories, heavy armor offers the best protection. These suits of armor cover the entire body and are designed to stop a wide range of attacks. Only proficient warriors can manage their weight and bulk.

entries.name: Ceramic Composite Armor.
entries: This armor is madeof Kevlar with thick ceramic composite plates sewn throughout and extra panels to provide fuller body coverage. This armor is bulky and restricts movement but can stop armor piercing rounds from a rifle. Wearing this in public would likely result in calls to the police. (45 lb., $800)

entries.name: Emergency Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Suit.
entries: This specialty protective gear is only worn by explosive ordnance disposal experts. It is very heavy and bulky, though it can absorb a large amount of damage if caught in an explosion. (80 lb., $4,000)

entries.name: Futuristic Exo-suit.
entries: This lightweight frame composed of advanced alloys protects the wearer's skeleton and major muscle and organ groups, as well as serves as an excellent platform on which Tech heroes and futuristic soldiers can mount high tech weaponry and equipment. However, it is obvious when worn, incredibly heavy, and undeniably loud. (120 lb., $1 million)
{@i Note: unless used to make a durable superhero costume, this item is only intended for games with science fiction or superadvanced technology, unless the GM decides otherwise.}

entries.name: Personal Mech.
entries: The personal mech is a high-tech battle armor not unlike the kind some higher-level Tech heroes might wear. It often features motorized arms and legs, as well as basic jump jets and gyros, all of which compensate for its heavy weight, requiring no body strength to operate. When in a personal mech, the wearer has a Strength of 20, as well as {@sense Darkvision} to 60 feet. (2000 lb., $10 million)
{@i Note: this item is only intended for games with science fiction or super-advanced technology.}

entries.name: Getting Into and Out of Armor
entries: The time it takes to don or doff armor depends on the armor's category.

entries.name: Don
entries: This is the time it takes to put on armor. You benefit from the armor's AC only if you take the full time to don the suit of armor.

entries.name: Doff
entries: This is the time it takes to take off armor. If you have help, reduce this time by half

entries.name: Shields
entries: A shield is usually made from plastic, such as a riot shield or tactical ballistic shield, and is carried in one hand. Wielding a riot shield increases your Armor Class by 2 and a tactical ballistic shield, or futuristic shield, by 3. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

entries.name: Riot Shield.
entries: General use modern polycarbonate shield used for crowd control and deflection of thrown projectiles. It is lightweight, protects the user, and can be used to bash as well. (10 lb., $75)

entries.name: Tactical Ballistic Shield.
entries: A specialized militarygrade shield that can deflect bullets, often made of aramidlaced plastic, with a viewing port (20 lb., $200)

entries.name: Futuristic Retractable Shield.
entries: A futuristic energy field projection based on the forearm. With an action, the wielder can project a translucent forcefield form the forearm to provide protection (1 lb., $10,000)

entries.name: Weapons
entries: Your background grants proficiency in certain weapons, reflecting both the class' focus and the tools you are most likely to use. Whether you favor a firearm or a hand-tohand weapon, your weapon, and your ability to wield it effectively, can mean the difference between life and death while adventuring.

The Weapons table shows the most common weapons used in modern fantasy gaming worlds, their price and weight, the damage they deal when they hit, and any special properties they possess. Every weapon is classified as either melee or ranged. A {@b melee weapon} is used to attack a target within 5 feet of you, whereas a {@b ranged weapon} is used to attack a target at a distance.

entries.name: Weapon Proficiency
entries: Your background and feats can grant you proficiency with certain weapons or categories of weapons. The two categories are simple and martial. Most people can use simple weapons with proficiency. These weapons include clubs, knives, and other weapons the average person might have some familiarity with, even if they do not have practice using it as a weapon in combat. Martial weapons, including swords, rifles, shotguns, and heavy weapons, require more specialized training to use effectively. Most soldiers use martial weapons because these weapons are more effective and put their training to best use.

Proficiency with a weapon allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it. If you make an attack roll using a weapon with which you lack proficiency, you do not add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll.

entries.name: Weapon Properties
entries: Many weapons have special properties related to their use, as shown in the Weapons table.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition.
For bows, hand-drawn crossbows, and hand crossbows, drawing ammunition from a quiver or case and loading your weapon is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a hand crossbow).

Some weapons can fire multiple pieces of ammunition in a single action. These weapons have the {@b semi-auto} or {@b full auto} properties. For weapons with the semi-auto and full auto modes, switching between modes is also part of the attack.

Bullets used in combat are spent, but arrows and bolts can be recovered afterwards. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended arrows or bolts by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons" later in the section).

entries.name: Capacity
entries: Weapons with the capacity property can hold a certain amount of ammunition before needing to be reloaded. In the chart below, the amount of ammunition each weapon can hold is listed in parentheses after the capacity property.

entries.name: Finesse
entries: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

entries.name: Full Auto
entries: Fully automatic weapons can fire a large amount of ammunition with a single attack, sometimes targeting more than person at once. When you use a such a weapon to make a full auto attack, choose one creature within normal range, or choose two creatures within normal range that are within 5 feet of each other, and make ranged attack rolls against them both. Treat your targets as though they have partial cover. On a hit, you double the damage dice rolled against each target, though not any damage modifiers. You may only use a Full Auto attack against targets within normal range; full auto attacks against targets at long range automatically miss. Full Auto attacks use five times the normal amount of ammunition, unless otherwise specified. You may only make one Full Auto attack per round. Weapons with the full auto property may also be fired in semi-auto mode.

entries.name: Futuristic
entries: Weapons with the futuristic tag are the stuff of science fiction. As such, players should assume such items are unavailable unless the GM explicitly allows it. They can also serve as equipment for invading aliens, super-advanced enemy soldiers, etc. The assumption is that futuristic equipment cannot be bought or repaired on 21st Century Earth unless your GM says so. Futuristic weapons fire laser blasts that do radiant damage. The ammunition is refilled with a laser capacitor, which resembles a magazine but contains condensed charges.
{@i Note: this item is only intended for games with science fiction or advanced technology.}

entries.name: Heavy
entries: Small creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small creature to use effectively.

entries.name: Light
entries: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

entries.name: Quick Loading
entries: Some weapons, like semiautomatic pistols and rifles, use quick loading magazines. When such a weapon runs out of ammunition, you may use either an action or a bonus action to reload it before firing again.

entries.name: Range
entries: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's long range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

entries.name: Reach
entries: This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it, as well as when determining your reach for opportunity attacks with it.

entries.name: Semi-Auto
entries: Semiautomatic weapons can fire several pieces of ammunition with a single attack. When you use a such a weapon to make a semiautomatic attack, choose one creature within normal or long range. On a hit, you add +2 to the damage rolled. Semiautomatic attacks use triple the normal amount of ammunition.

entries.name: Slow Loading
entries: Some weapons, like revolvers, shotguns, and compound crossbows, require reloading one piece of ammunition at a time. This takes time. When such a weapon runs out of ammunition, you must spend an action reloading it before firing again.

entries.name: Special
entries: A weapon with the special property has unusual rules governing its use, explained in the weapon's description (see "Special Weapons" later in this section).

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a hand axe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

entries.name: Two-Handed
entries: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

entries.name: Versatile
entries: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

entries.name: Improvised Weapons
entries: An improvised weapon includes any object you can wield in one or two hands, such as broken glass, a table leg, a frying pan, a wagon wheel, or a corpse.

Often, an improvised weapon is like an actual weapon and can be treated as such. For example, a table leg is akin to a club. At the GM's option, a character proficient with a weapon can use a similar object as if it were that weapon and use their proficiency bonus.

An object that bears no resemblance to a weapon deals {@damage 1d4} damage (the GM assigns a damage type appropriate to the object). If a character uses a ranged weapon to make a melee attack or throws a melee weapon that does not have the thrown property, it also deals {@damage 1d4} damage. An improvised thrown weapon has a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Special Weapons
entries: Weapons with special rules are described here.

entries.name: Bayonet
entries: A bayonet can be affixed to the barrel of a rifle or shotgun, allowing the gun to be used as a melee weapon.

entries.name: Boomerang
entries: A boomerang will return to the thrower when thrown if it misses its target.

entries.name: Chainsaw
entries: Because chainsaws are not intended as weapons, their weight and size make them poor weapons, not to mention dangerous. Chainsaws also require gasoline to operate and are very loud, making noise that can be heard up to 150 feet away.

entries.name: Flamethrower
entries: This heavy ranged weapon belches a line of flame 60 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each target in range must make a DC 12 Dexterity save or take {@dice 3d6} fire, half on a save. A flamethrower holds enough fuel for three rounds of attack before a new cannister must be loaded.

entries.name: Grenade, fragmentation
entries: These weapons are thrown at a visible location in range. All creatures within fifteen feet of the target must succeed at a DC 15 Dexterity save or take {@damage 3d6} fire damage, or half on a successful save. Once used, they are destroyed.

entries.name: Grenade, rocket propelled
entries: These weapons are launched at a visible location in range. All creatures within twenty feet of the target must succeed at a DC 15 Dexterity save or take {@damage 4d10} fire damage, or half on a successful save. Once used, they are destroyed.

entries.name: Grenade, smoke
entries: These weapons are thrown at a visible location in range. Once thrown, they fill a 20-foot-radius sphere around the target with opaque smoke. It lasts for 1 minute or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. Once used, they are destroyed.

entries.name: Grenade, stun
entries: These weapons are thrown at a visible location in range. All creatures who can see or hear within ten feet of the target must make a DC 15 CON save or be {@condition blinded} and {@condition deafened} for 3 rounds. Once used, they are destroyed.

entries.name: Machine gun, heavy
entries: This heavy, 50 caliber, powerful weapon can be carried but not fired, unless the user has a Strength score of 20 or higher. It can be fired with a collapsible tripod attached to its underside, which takes an Action to set up.

entries.name: Minigun
entries: The minigun is a motorized, six barreled, vehicle mounted machine gun that shoots roughly 3000 rounds per minute. When the trigger is pulled, the minigun takes one round to spin up before it begins to shoot. Once it begins shooting, it releases 300 bullets a round—that's 50 bullets a second—at its target or targets. Miniguns fire with Disadvantage against moving targets of Medium size or smaller. If fired for a full minute, the weapon overheats and cannot be used for five minutes afterwards.

entries.name: Missile, Ballistic
entries: These weapons are sometimes mounted on vehicles or installed in batteries on the ground, though they can also be mounted on jets and helicopters. They can even be carried and fired from the shoulder, as in the case of an anti-tank weapon like a Javelin, though it requires two people to load and fire it. Unlike guided missiles, these weapons must be aimed. When you fire a ballistic missile, make a ranged weapon attack. This may involve interacting with a computer screen or a heads-up display. The missile is destroyed when used.

entries.name: Missile, guided, large
entries: A large, guided missile, such as a Tomahawk, which is launched from a large sea vessel or submarine. To fire a guided missile, you must first input a location in space into the targeting computer. Once fired, the missile flies to its chosen location. When it hits, every creature in a 30-foot radius of its point of impact takes the listed damage, or half on a successful DC 20 Dexterity save.

entries.name: Missile, guided, small
entries: A small, guided missile, suchas a Hellfire, which is mounted to a vehicle, such as a drone or other aircraft, or shot from a platform, such as the deck of ship. To fire a guided missile, you must first input a location in space into the targeting computer. Once fired, the missile flies to its chosen location. When it hits, every creature in a 30-foot radius of its point of impact takes the listed damage, or half on a successful DC 18 Dexterity save.

entries.name: Net
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect, and destroying the net.
When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make

entries.name: Pepper spray
entries: When you hit a target with pepper spray who has open eyes, they must make a Dexterity save, DC13, or be {@condition blinded} for one minute.

entries.name: Shotgun sawed off
entries: Sawed off shotguns shoot in a wide spread. When firing, choose up to two creatures in range within 5 feet of each other, and make attack rolls against both.

entries.name: Tank gun
entries: These 120mm smoothbore guns are mounted atop tanks such as the M1 Abrams. They fire a variety of shells, but the one listed below is an anti-tank variety, designed to pierce tank armor at distances up to a mile. There are other shells with shotgun like cones of effect for use against personnel.

entries.name: Taser
entries: This weapon uses conducted electricity to stun targets. It shoots two small darts that conduct high voltage electricity. On a hit, the target takes 2 lightning damage and must make a CON save, DC 13, or be {@condition stunned} for 3 rounds.

entries.name: Gear
entries: This section describes items that have special rules or require further explanation.

entries.name: Equipment Packs
entries: The starting equipment you get from your background includes a collection of useful adventuring gear, put together in a pack. The contents of these packs are listed here with their cost in dollars. If you are buying your starting equipment, you can purchase a pack for the price shown, which might be cheaper than buying the items individually.

entries.name: {@item Criminal's Pack} (175)
entries: backpack, casual clothes, flashlight, flask, lighter, 2 packed meals, nylon rope, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Journalist's Pack} (300)
entries: Backpack, batteries, DSLR camera, casual clothes, coffee mug, notebook, 2 packed meals, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Laborer's Pack} (180)
entries: backpack, batteries, chalk, casual clothes, crowbar, gasoline can (filled), hammer, ladder, 2 packed meals, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Medic's Pack} (200)
entries: backpack, antitoxin (vial), casual clothes, first aid kit, 2 packed meals, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Office Worker's Pack} (350)
entries: briefcase, coffee mug, dress clothes, laptop, notebook, 2 packed meals, perfume, smart phone, soap.

entries.name: {@item Police Officer's Pack} (200)
entries: backpack, official uniform, flashlight, handcuffs, 2 packed meals, baton, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Scientist's Pack} (375):
entries: briefcase, acid (vial), book, dress clothes, laptop, notebook, 2 packed meals, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Student's Pack} (300)
entries: backpack, batteries, blanket, book, casual clothes, coffee mug, laptop, lighter, notebook, 2 packed meals, smart phone, water bottle.

entries.name: {@item Survivalist's Pack} (250)
entries: backpack, bedroll, binoculars, blanket, climber's kit, casual clothes, fishing tackle, flashlight, hunting trap, lighter, mess kit, 5 packed meals, nylon rope, shovel, tent, water bottle.

entries.name: Tools
entries: A tool helps you to do something you couldn't otherwise do, such as craft or repair an item, forge a document, maneuver a vehicle, or pick a lock. Your culture, class, background, or feats give you proficiency with certain tools. Proficiency with a tool allows you to add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make using that tool. Tool use is not tied to a single ability since proficiency with a tool represents broader knowledge of its use. For example, the GM might ask you to make a Dexterity check to maneuver a car down a road littered with dangerous debris, or a Wisdom check to change the car's oil. Having proficiency in Vehicles (land) allows you to add your proficiency bonus to checks such as these.

entries.name: Expenses
entries: When not descending into the depths of the Earth, exploring ruins for lost treasures, or waging war against the encroaching darkness, heroes face more mundane realities. Even in a fictional world, people require necessities such as shelter, sustenance, and clothing. These things cost money, although some lifestyles cost more than others.

entries.name: Lifestyle Expenses
entries: Lifestyle expenses provide you with a simple way to account for the cost of living in your S5E world. They cover your accommodations, food and drink, and all your other necessities. Furthermore, expenses cover the cost of maintaining your equipment so you can be ready when duty next calls. The amounts provided are average prices for cities in the developed world for the purposes of game play. because the modern world has such variance in the cost of living, no one accurate amount can be provided for every situation. GMs should adjust these significantly if the characters are living in an extremely expensive or impoverished area, for example.

At the start of each week or month (your choice), choose a lifestyle from the Expenses table and pay the price to sustain that lifestyle. The prices listed are per day. Your lifestyle might change from one period to the next, based on the funds you have at your disposal, or you might maintain the same lifestyle throughout your character's career.

Your lifestyle choice can have consequences. Maintaining a wealthy lifestyle might help you make contacts with the rich and powerful, though you run the risk of attracting thieves. Likewise, living frugally might help you avoid criminals, but you are unlikely to make powerful connections.

entries.name: Wretched
entries: You live in inhumane conditions. With no place to call home, you shelter wherever you can, sleeping on the streets, huddling in old crates, and relying on the good graces of people better off than you. A wretched lifestyle presents abundant dangers. Violence, disease, and hunger follow you wherever you go. Other wretched people covet your possessions, which represent a fortune by their standards. You are beneath the notice of most people.

entries.name: Squalid
entries: You live in a tiny closet of a room, in a desolate area of the city. The roof leaks and it is vermin infested. You have shelter from the elements, but you live in a desperate and often violent environment, in places rife with disease, hunger, and misfortune. You are beneath the notice of most people, and you have few legal protections. Most people at this lifestyle level have suffered some terrible setback. They might be disturbed, marked as exiles, or suffer from disease.

entries.name: Poor
entries: A poor lifestyle means going without the comforts available in a stable community. Simple food and lodgings, threadbare clothing, and unpredictable conditions result in a sufficient, though probably unpleasant, experience. Your accommodations might be a room in public housing or in a small apartment in a poor neighborhood. You benefit from some legal protections, but you still must contend with violence, crime, and disease. People at this lifestyle level tend to be unskilled laborers, service industry workers, and students, as well as criminals and other disreputable types.

entries.name: Modest
entries: A modest lifestyle keeps you out of the slums and ensures that you can maintain your equipment. You live in an older part of town, renting an apartment, most likely, or sharing a small house with roommates. You don't go hungry or thirsty, and your living conditions are clean, if simple. Ordinary people living modest lifestyles include police officers, teachers, nurses, journalists, skilled laborers, and the like. Comfortable. You can afford nicer clothing and can easily maintain your equipment. You live in a small house or a nice apartment in a middle-class neighborhood. You associate with white collar workers, retail managers, and small business owners, among others.

entries.name: Wealthy
entries: You live a life of luxury, though you might not have achieved the social status associated with the old money of nobility or royalty. This lifestyle is comparable to that of a highly successful business owner, a professional athlete or successful musician, or perhaps you inherited your money. You have respectable lodgings, usually a spacious home in a good part of town or a comfortable suite at a fine hotel. You likely pay someone to manage housekeeping and garden maintenance, among other things.

entries.name: Fabulously Wealthy
entries: You live a life of plenty and comfort, moving in circles populated by the most powerful people in the community. You have excellent lodgings, perhaps a townhouse in the nicest part of town or a large manor house in a tastefully remote suburb. You dine at the best restaurants, retain the most skilled and fashionable tailor, and have servants attending to your every need. You receive invitations to the social gatherings of the rich and powerful, and spend evenings in the company of politicians, CEOs, and celebrities. You must also contend with the highest levels of deceit and treachery, since the wealthier you are, the greater the chance you will be drawn into political intrigue as a pawn or participant.

entries.name: Food, Drink, Lodging
entries: It is assumed that players are familiar with the cost of goods such as bread, cheese, meat, and liquor in the modern world, so a table is not provided here. Hotel prices range from $50/night for a cheap motel, to $150/ night for a decent chain hotel, to $500/night or more for luxury accommodations.

entries.name: Modern Vehicles
entries: A good vehicle can get you from A to B much faster than you could get there on foot. A reliable bike, car, cab, train, boat, or plane can be critical for saving time and even lives. The Vehicles tables show each vehicle's cost, speed, and base carrying capacity.

items: {@i Travel time}. It is assumed that players are familiar with travel times for the most common forms of transportation.

{@i Damage Resistance}. Most vehicles, especially military and combat models, can withstand a lot of damage. Vehicles that are larger, heavier, or militarized have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage. The vehicles table indicates which vehicles have this damage resistance.

{@i Hit points}. Vehicles also have HP. Once a vehicle loses half of its HP, it loses some functionality. Any roll someone makes to pilot such a vehicle is rolled with disadvantage. The vehicle is disabled entirely when the HP drop to zero. The HP are also listed in the table below.

{@i Fueled}. Except for the bicycle and horses, listed below, all vehicles need fuel—though horses need stabling and food, of course. Fuel for cars and trucks is easy enough to obtain, but fuel for planes, helicopters, and military craft is extremely difficult outside of an airport or military installation. GMs can decide whether or how to allow characters access to such fuel.

data.name: Leveling Up
entries: This chapter provides instructions for leveling up your hero, including the rules for multiclassing.

entries.name: Leveling Up
entries: As your hero fights crime and overcomes challenges, they gain competence, represented by experience points. A character who reaches a specified experience point total advances in capability. This advancement is called {@b gaining a level}.

entries.name: Ability Score Increases and Feats
entries: When your character gains a level, their class often grants additional features, as detailed in the class description. Some of these features allow you to increase your ability scores, either increasing two scores by 1 each or increasing one score by 2. (You can't increase an ability score above 26.) In addition, every character's proficiency bonus increases at certain levels.

Each time you gain a level, you gain 1 additional Hit Die. You can use the fixed value shown in your class entry, which is the average result of the die roll (rounded up). Alternatively, you may roll your Hit Die, add your Constitution modifier to the roll, and add the total to your hit point maximum.

When your Constitution modifier increases by 1, your HP maximum increases by 1 for each level you have attained. For example, if your 7th-level fighter has a Constitution score of 17, when she reaches 8th level, she increases her Constitution score from 17 to 18, thus increasing her Constitution modifier from +3 to +4, so HP maximum then increases by 8.

The Character Advancement table summarizes the XP you need to advance in levels from level 1 through level 20, and the proficiency bonus for a character of that level. Consult the information in your character's class description to see what other improvements you gain at each level.
When you are given the option to increase your ability scores, you may instead choose a feat. The list of feats and instructions for choosing them can be found in Chapter Four.

entries.name: Multiclassing
entries: Multiclassing allows you to gain levels in multiple classes, letting you mix the abilities of those classes to realize a character concept that might not be reflected in one of the standard class options.

With this rule, you have the option of gaining a level in a new class whenever you advance in level, instead of gaining a level in your current class. You may not select the same class a second time to gain another subclass, however.
Your levels in all your classes are added together to determine your character level. For example, if you have three levels in Kinetic and two in Martial Expert, you're a 5th-level character.

As you advance in levels, you might primarily remain a member of your original class with just a few levels in another class, or you might change course entirely, abandoning advancement in the class you left behind, or you could start progressing in a third or fourth class. Compared to a single-class character of the same level, you'll exchange focus for versatility.

entries.name: Prerequisites
entries: To qualify for a new class, you must meet the ability score prerequisites for both your current class and your new one, as shown in the Multiclassing Prerequisites table. For example, an Elementalist who decides to multiclass into the Tech class must have an Intelligence score of 13 or higher. Without the full training that a beginning character receives, you must be a quick study in your new class, having a natural aptitude that is reflected by higher-than-average ability scores.

entries.name: Experience Points
entries: The experience point cost to gain a level is always based on your total character level, as shown in the Character Advancement table, not your level in a particular class. So, if you are a Mentalist 6/Agent 1, you must gain enough XP to reach 8th level before you can take your second level as an agent or your seventh level as a Mentalist.

entries.name: Hit Points & Hit Dice
entries: You gain the HP from your new class as described for levels after 1st. You gain the 1st-level HP for a class only when you are a 1st-level character.

You add together the Hit Dice granted by all your classes to form your pool of Hit Dice. If the Hit Dice are the same die type, you can simply pool them together. For example, both the Elementalist and the Kinetic have a {@dice d10}, so if you are a Kinetic 5/Elementalist 5, you have ten {@dice d10} Hit Dice. If your classes give you Hit Dice of different types, keep track of them separately. If you are a Kinetic 5/Mystic 5, for example, you have five {@dice d10} Hit Dice and five {@dice d8} Hit Dice.

entries.name: Proficiency Bonus
entries: Your proficiency bonus is always based on your total character level, as shown in the Character Advancement table, not your level in a particular class.

entries.name: Class Features
entries: When you gain a new level in a class, you get its features for that level. You don't, however, or receive the class' starting equipment. Furthermore, if two classes grant the same feature, you only receive it once, for example, {@b Extra Attack}.

entries.name: Extra Attack
entries: If you gain the Extra Attack class feature from more than one class, the features don't add together.
You can't make more than two attacks with this feature unless it says you do (as the Martial Expert's version of Extra Attack does).

entries.name: Using Powers
entries: Your capacity to use superpowers depends on your individual levels in classes that grant powers. Once you have a powers feature from more than one class, use the rules below. If you multiclass but have a power feature from only one class, you follow the rules as described in that class.

entries.name: Powers Known and Prepared
entries: You determine what powers you know and can prepare for each class individually, as if you were a single-classed member of that class.
Each power you know and prepare is associated with one of your classes, and you use the power ability of that class when you use the power.

entries.name: Power Slots
entries: You earn power slots from each class individually, as if you were a single-classed member of that class.

Reflexive Power Slots are not interchangeable, however, and only grant you the ability to use reflexive power slots with powers of the power list of the class that granted you reflexive slots, as well as with general powers.

Thus, if you multiclass with two classes that have power slots, you must note which powers are on which class lists, so you can determine whether you may use those powers reflexively or not. General powers can be used with any regular or reflexive power slot.
In cases where one of your classes does not have powers, like Special Agent or Martial Expert, you only have powers at the levels gained from your power using classes.

entries.name: Multiclass Powers Example
entries: Known and prepared powers: If you are an Elementalist 2/Tech 3, for example, you know 4 1st-level Elementalist powers based on your levels in the Elementalist class. As a 3rd-level Tech hero with Intelligence is 16, you can prepare 6 Tech powers from the Tech and general power lists.

Reflexive Power slots: if you are, say, a Kinetic 1/Vitalist 2, you have three 1st-level power slots from your Vitalist levels and two 1st-level slots from your Kinetic levels. This gives you 5 1st-level slots, which you can expend interchangeably to use any of the Elementalist or Vitalist powers you know.

If you are a Kinetic 3/Vitalist 2, you have three 1st-level slots from your Vitalist levels and two 2nd-level slots from your Kinetic levels. You can also use Kinetic and general 1st-level powers reflexively. You cannot use any 1st-level Vitalist powers reflexively, however, because having 1st-level reflexive powers is associated with being a 3rd-level Kinetic hero only.
Only the class-specific powers are limited in this way, however. You can use any of your 1st-level General powers reflexively, even if you gained them via the Vitalist class.

data.name: Rules
entries: This chapter contains almost all the rules you need to run a game of S5E! See Chapter Eight for the rules for powers, as well as the class power lists and the index of powers.

entries.name: Using Ability Scores
entries: Six abilities provide a quick description of every creature's physical and mental characteristics:
Is a character muscle-bound and insightful? Brilliant and charming? Nimble and hardy? Ability scores define these qualities—a creature's assets as well as weaknesses.

The three main rolls of the game—the {@b ability check}, the {@b saving throw}, and the {@b attack roll}—rely on the six ability scores. In brief, all actions boil down to this: roll a {@dice d20}, add an ability modifier derived from one of the six ability scores, and compare the total to a target number.

entries.name: Ability Scores & Modifiers
entries: Each of a creature's abilities has a score, a number that defines the magnitude of that ability. An ability score is not just a measure of innate capabilities, but also encompasses a creature's training and competence in activities related to that ability.

A score of 10 or 11 is the normal human average, but many heroes and supernatural creatures are a cut above ordinary in most abilities. A score of 18 is the highest that a non-powered person usually reaches. Superheroes can have scores as high as 26.

Each ability also has a modifier, derived from the score and ranging from -5 (for an ability score of 1) to +10 (for a score of 30). The Ability Scores and Modifiers' table notes the ability modifiers for the range of possible ability scores, from 1 to 30.
To determine an ability modifier without consulting the table, subtract 10 from the ability score and then divide the total by 2 (round down).
Because ability modifiers affect almost every attack roll, ability check, and save, ability modifiers come up in play more often than their associated scores.

entries.name: Advantage & Disadvantage
entries: Sometimes a special ability or power tells you that you have advantage or disadvantage on an ability check, a saving throw, or an attack roll. When that happens, you roll two d20s when you make the roll. Use the higher of the two rolls if you have advantage or the lower roll if you have disadvantage. For example, if you have disadvantage and roll a 17 and a 5, you use the 5. If you instead had advantage, you use the 17.

If multiple situations affect a roll and each one grants advantage or imposes disadvantage on it, you never roll more than one extra {@dice d20}. If two favorable situations grant advantage, you still roll only one additional {@dice d20}.

If circumstances cause a roll to have both advantage and disadvantage, you are considered to have neither of them, so you roll one {@dice d20}. This is true even if multiple circumstances impose disadvantage and only one grants advantage or vice versa. In such a situation, you have neither advantage nor disadvantage.

When you have advantage or disadvantage and something in the game that lets you reroll the {@dice d20} (such as the Good Luck feat), you can reroll only one of the dice. You choose which one. For example, if a hero has advantage or disadvantage on an ability check and rolls a 1 and a 13, the hero could use the Lucky trait to reroll the 1.

You usually gain advantage or disadvantage using special abilities, actions, or powers. Inspiration can also give a character advantage. The GM can also decide that circumstances influence a roll in one direction or the other and grant advantage or impose disadvantage as a result.

entries.name: Proficiency Bonus
entries: Characters have a proficiency bonus determined by level.
Creatures and villains also have this bonus, which is incorporated in their stat blocks. The bonus is used in the rules on ability checks, saves, and attack rolls.

Unless a feature explicitly states that you should add it twice, your proficiency bonus is only added once to a single die roll or other number. For example, if two different rules say you can add your proficiency bonus to a Wisdom save, you nevertheless add the bonus only once when you make the save.
Occasionally, your proficiency bonus might be doubled or halved before you apply it by a feature or power.

For example, if you have the Kinetic feature Physical Acumen, your proficiency bonus may double when you roll {@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}. With a feature like the Special Agent's Broad Training, on the other hand, you can add half your proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check you make that doesn't already include your proficiency bonus.
In general, you don't multiply your proficiency bonus for attack rolls or saves. If a feature or effect allows you to do so, these same rules apply.

To make an ability check, roll a {@dice d20} and add the relevant ability modifier. As with other {@dice d20} rolls, apply bonuses and penalties, and compare the total to the DC. If the total equals or exceeds the DC, the ability check is a success—the creature overcomes the challenge at hand. Otherwise, it's a failure, which means the character or Creature makes no progress toward the objective or makes progress combined with a setback determined by the GM.

entries.name: Contests
entries: Sometimes one character's or Creature's efforts are directly opposed to another's. This can occur when both are trying to do the same thing and only one can succeed, such as attempting to snatch up a weapon that has fallen on the floor. This situation also applies when one is trying to prevent the other from accomplishing a goal—for example, when a villain tries to force open a door that a hero is holding closed. In situations like these, the outcome is determined by a special form of ability check, called a contest.

Both participants in a contest make ability checks appropriate to their efforts. They apply all appropriate bonuses and penalties, but instead of comparing the total to a DC, they compare the totals of their two checks. The participant with the higher total check wins the contest. That character or villain either succeeds at the action or prevents the other from succeeding.

If the contest results in a tie, the situation remains the same as it was before the contest. Thus, one contestant might win the contest by default. A tie in a contest to snatch a weapon off the floor, neither character grabs it. In a contest trying to open a door, a tie means that the door remains shut.

entries.name: Skills
entries: Each ability covers a broad range of capabilities, including skills that characters or NPCs can be proficient in. A skill represents a specific aspect of an ability score, and an individual's proficiency in a skill demonstrates a focus on that aspect. (A character's starting skill proficiencies are determined at character creation, and a NPC's skill proficiencies appear in their stat block.)

For example, a Dexterity check might reflect a character's attempt at an acrobatic stunt, to palm an object, or to stay hidden. Each of these aspects of Dexterity has an associated skill: {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Sleight of Hand}, and {@skill Stealth}, respectively. So, a character who has proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill is particularly good at Dexterity checks related to sneaking and hiding.

Which skills relate to each ability score are shown in the following list. (No skills are related to Constitution.) See an ability's description below for examples of how to use a skill associated with an ability.

entries.name: Strength
entries: {@skill Athletics}

entries.name: Dexterity
entries: {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Slight of Hand}, {@skill Stealth}

entries.name: Constitution
entries: Concentration

entries.name: Intelligence
entries: {@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, {@skill arcana|phb|Mysticism}, {@skill Science}, {@skill Technology}

entries.name: Wisdom
entries: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Insight}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Survial}

entries.name: Charisma
entries: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Performance}, {@skill Persuasion}

Sometimes, the GM might ask for an ability check using a specific skill—for example, "Make a {@skill Perception} check. At other times, a player might ask the GM if proficiency in a particular skill applies to a check. In either case, proficiency in a skill means an individual can add their proficiency bonus to ability checks that involve that skill. Without proficiency in the skill, the individual makes a normal ability check.

For example, if a character attempts to climb up a dangerous cliff, the GM might ask for an {@skill Athletics} check. A character proficient in {@skill Athletics}, would add their proficiency bonus to the Strength check. If the character lacks that proficiency, they just make a Strength check.

entries.name: Different Abilities & Skill Checks
entries: Normally, your proficiency in a skill applies only to a specific kind of ability check. Proficiency in {@skill Athletics}, for example, usually applies to certain Strength checks. In some situations, though, your proficiency might reasonably apply to a different kind of check. In such cases, the GM might ask for a check using an unusual combination of ability and skill, or you might ask your GM if you can apply a proficiency to a different check.

Say you must swim from an offshore island to the mainland, your GM might call for a Constitution check to see if you have the stamina to make it that far. In this case, your GM might allow you to apply your proficiency in {@skill Athletics} and ask for a Constitution ({@skill Athletics}) check. So, if you're proficient in {@skill Athletics}, you apply your proficiency bonus to the Constitution check just as you would normally do for an {@skill Athletics} check. Similarly, when your Kinetic strength hero uses a display of raw strength to intimidate an enemy, your GM might ask for a Strength ({@skill Intimidation}) check, even though {@skill Intimidation} is normally associated with Charisma.

entries.name: Passive Checks
entries: A passive check is a special kind of ability check that doesn't involve any die rolls. Such a check can represent the average result for a task done repeatedly, such as searching for secret doors repeatedly or can be used when the GM wants to secretly determine whether the characters succeed at something without rolling dice, such as noticing a hidden villain.
Here's how to determine a character's total for a passive check:
{@b 10 + all modifiers that normally apply to the check}
If the character has advantage on the check, add 5. For disadvantage, subtract 5. A passive check total is called a "{@b score}".

entries.name: Working Together
entries: Sometimes characters team up to attempt a task. The character who's leading the effort—or the one with the highest ability modifier—can make an ability check with advantage, reflecting the help provided by the other characters. In combat, this requires the {@action Help} action.

A character can only provide help if the task is one that they could attempt alone. For example, trying to open a lock requires proficiency with thieves' tools, so a character who lacks that proficiency can't help another character in that task. Moreover, a character can help only when two or more individuals working together would be productive. Some tasks, such as threading a needle, are no easier with help.

entries.name: Group Checks
entries: When several individuals are trying to accomplish something as a group, the GM might ask for a {@b group ability check}. In such a situation, the characters who are skilled at a particular task help cover those who aren't.
To make a group ability check, everyone in the group makes the ability check. If at least half the group succeeds, the whole group succeeds. Otherwise, the group fails.

For example, when heroes are navigating a swamp, the GM might call for a group {@skill Survival} check to see if the characters can avoid the quicksand, sinkholes, and other natural hazards of the environment. If at least half the group succeeds, the successful characters can guide their companions out of danger. Otherwise, the group stumbles into one of these hazards.

entries.name: Using Each Ability
entries: Every task that a character or NPC might attempt in the game is covered by one of the six abilities. This section explains in more detail what those abilities mean and the ways they are used in the game.

entries.name: Strength
entries: Strength measures bodily power, athletic training, and the extent to which you can exert raw physical force.

entries.name: Strength Checks
entries: A Strength check can model any attempt to lift, push, pull, or break something, to force your body through a space, or to otherwise apply brute force to a situation. The {@skill Athletics} skill reflects aptitude in certain kinds of Strength checks.

entries.name: Athletics
entries: {@skill Athletics} checks cover difficult situations you encounter while climbing, jumping, or swimming.

entries.name: Other Strength Checks
entries: The GM might also call for a Strength check when you try to accomplish tasks like forcing open, breaking free of, pushing through, or hanging onto something.

entries.name: Attack Rolls and Damage
entries: You add your Strength modifier to your attack roll and your damage roll when attacking with any melee weapon. You use melee weapons to make close attacks in handto-hand combat, but some can also be thrown to make a ranged attack.

entries.name: Lifting and Carrying
entries: Your Strength score determines the amount of weight you can bear. The following terms define what you can lift or carry.

entries.name: Carrying Capacity
entries: Your carrying capacity is your Strength score multiplied by 15. This is the weight (in pounds) that you can carry.

entries.name: Push, Drag, or Lift
entries: You can push, drag, or lift a weight in pounds up to twice your carrying capacity (or 30 times your Strength score). While pushing or dragging weight more than your carrying capacity, your speed drops to 5 feet.

entries.name: Size and Strength
entries: Larger creatures can bear more weight, whereas Tiny creatures can carry less. For each size category above Medium, double the creature's carrying capacity and the amount it can push, drag, or lift. For a Tiny creature, halve these weights.

entries.name: Dexterity
entries: Dexterity measures agility, reflexes, and balance.

entries.name: Dexterity Checks
entries: A Dexterity check models any attempt to move nimbly, quickly, or quietly, or to keep from falling on poor footing. The {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Sleight of Hand}, and {@skill Stealth} skills reflect aptitude in certain kinds of Dexterity checks.

entries.name: Acrobatics
entries: Your {@skill Acrobatics} check covers your attempt to stay on your feet in a tricky situation, such as when you're trying to run across a sheet of ice, balance on a tightrope, or stay upright on top of a moving truck. The GM might also use an {@skill Acrobatics} check to see if you can perform acrobatic stunts, including dives, rolls, somersaults, and flips.

entries.name: Sleight of Hand
entries: Whenever you attempt an act of legerdemain or manual trickery, such as planting something on someone else or concealing an object on your person, make a {@skill Sleight of Hand} check. The GM might also use a {@skill Sleight of Hand} check to determine whether you can lift a purse off another person or slip something out of another person's pocket.

entries.name: Stealth
entries: Make a {@skill Stealth} check when you attempt to conceal yourself from enemies, slink past guards, slip away without being noticed, or sneak up on someone without being seen or heard.

entries.name: Other Dexterity Checks
entries: The GM might call for a Dexterity check when you try to accomplish any tasks requiring either gross or fine motor skills, such as piloting a plane around obstacles.

entries.name: Attack Rolls and Damage
entries: You add your Dexterity modifier to your attack roll and your damage roll when attacking with any ranged weapon.
