You can also add your Dexterity modifier to your attack roll and your damage roll when attacking with a melee weapon that has the finesse property.

entries.name: Constitution
entries: Constitution measures health, stamina, and vital force.

entries.name: Constitution Checks
entries: Constitution checks are uncommon, and no skills apply to Constitution checks, because the endurance this ability represents is largely passive rather than involving any specific effort. A Constitution check can model your attempt to push beyond normal limits, however.
The GM might call for a Constitution check when you try to accomplish tasks like holding your breath, marching without rest, surviving without sleep or food, or to avoid vomiting.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: Your Constitution modifier contributes to your health. Typically, you add your Constitution modifier to each Hit Die you roll for your HP.
If your Constitution modifier changes, your hit point maximum changes as well, as though you had the new modifier from 1st level.

entries.name: Intelligence
entries: Intelligence measures mental acuity, accuracy of recall, and the ability to reason.

entries.name: Intelligence Checks
entries: An Intelligence check comes into play when you need an aptitude for drawing on logic, education, memory, or deductive reasoning.

entries.name: History
entries: Your {@skill History} check measures your ability to recall lore about historical events, legendary people, past disputes, recent wars, and lost civilizations.

entries.name: Investigation
entries: When you look around for clues and make deductions based on those clues, you make an {@skill Investigation} check. You might deduce the location of a hidden object, discern from the appearance of a wound what kind of weapon dealt it, or determine the weakest point in a tunnel that could cause it to collapse, or poring through online databases in search of hidden data.

entries.name: Mysticism
entries: Your Mysticism check measures your ability to recall lore about the occult, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, the planes of existence, and the inhabitants of those planes.

entries.name: Science
entries: Your Science check determines how much you know about the natural world and its laws, your scientific understanding and expertise. It also measures your ability to recall information about terrain, plants and animals, the weather, and natural cycles.

entries.name: Technology
entries: Your Technology check measures how much you know about computers, electronics, programming, robotics, telephony, and other technological matters. Whereas Science concerns the general, abstract physical laws that govern technology, Technology concerns the particular facts about operating systems, exploits, models, protocols, and so on, as well as the ability to repair or modify devices.

entries.name: Other Intelligence Checks
entries: The GM might call for an Intelligence check when you try to accomplish tasks like communicate without using words, estimating the value of a precious item, recalling information, or winning a game of skill.

entries.name: Wisdom
entries: Wisdom reflects how attuned you are to the world around you and represents erudition and intuition.

entries.name: Wisdom Checks
entries: A Wisdom check might reflect an effort to read body language, understand someone's feelings, notice things about the environment, or care for an injured person.

entries.name: Animal Handling
entries: When there is any question whether you can calm down a domesticated animal, control a mount, or intuit an animal's intentions, the GM might call for an {@skill Animal Handling} check.

entries.name: Insight
entries: Your {@skill Insight} check decides whether you can determine the true intentions of a creature, such as when searching out a lie or predicting someone's next move. Doing so involves gleaning clues from body language, speech habits, and changes in mannerisms.

entries.name: Medicine
entries: A {@skill Medicine} check lets you try to stabilize a dying companion or diagnose an illness.

entries.name: Perception
entries: Your {@skill Perception} check lets you spot, hear, or otherwise detect the presence of something. It measures your general awareness of your surroundings and the keenness of your senses. For example, you might try to hear a conversation through a closed door, eavesdrop under an open window, or hear villains moving stealthily in the forest.

entries.name: Survival
entries: The GM might ask you to make a {@skill Survival} check to follow tracks, hunt, guide your group through frozen wastelands, identify signs that bears live nearby, predict the weather, or avoid quicksand and other natural hazards.

entries.name: Other Wisdom Checks
entries: The GM might call for a Wisdom check when you try to accomplish tasks like understanding gut feelings or discerning whether a seemingly dead or living creature is undead.

entries.name: Charisma
entries: Charisma measures your ability to interact effectively with others. It includes such factors as confidence, eloquence, and a charming or commanding personality.

entries.name: Charisma Checks
entries: A Charisma check might arise when you try to influence or entertain others, make an impression, or tell a convincing lie, or navigate a tricky social situation.

entries.name: Deception
entries: Your {@skill Deception} check determines whether you can convincingly hide the truth, through either actions or speech. This deception can encompass everything from misleading through ambiguity to outright lies. Typical situations include trying to fast-talk a guard, con a salesclerk, earn money through gambling, pass in a disguise, dull someone's suspicions with false assurances, or maintain a straight face while telling a blatant lie.

entries.name: Intimidation
entries: When you attempt to influence someone through overt threats, hostile actions, and physical violence, the GM might ask you to make an {@skill Intimidation} check. Examples include trying to pry information out of a prisoner, convincing street thugs to back down, or using a weapon to convince a sneering bureaucrat to reconsider a decision.

entries.name: Performance
entries: Your {@skill Performance} check determines how well you can delight an audience with music, dance, acting, storytelling, or some other form of entertainment.

entries.name: Persuasion
entries: When you attempt to influence someone or a group of people with tact, social graces, or good nature, the GM might ask you to make a {@skill Persuasion} check. Typically, you use persuasion when acting in good faith, to foster friendships, make cordial requests, or exhibit proper etiquette. Examples of persuading others include convincing an assistant to let your party see the CEO, negotiating peace between warring gangs, or inspiring a crowd of citizens.

entries.name: Other Charisma Checks
entries: The GM might call for a Charisma check when you try to accomplish tasks like finding a source for news, rumors, and gossip, or blend into a crowd to get the sense of the conversation.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: A saving throw—also called a save—represents an attempt to resist a threat, a power, trap, poison, or disease. You don't normally decide to make a save; you are forced to make one because of risk of harm.

To make a save, roll a {@dice d20} and add the appropriate ability modifier. For example, you use your Dexterity modifier for a Dexterity saving throw. Each class gives proficiency in at least two saving throws.
A saving throw can be modified by a situational bonus or penalty and can be affected by advantage and disadvantage, as determined by the GM.

The Difficulty Class for a save is determined by the effect that causes it. For example, the DC for a save allowed by a power is determined by the user's power ability and proficiency bonus. The result of a successful or failed saving throw is also detailed in the effect that allows the save. Usually, a successful save means that a creature suffers no harm, or reduced harm, from an effect.

entries.name: Tools, Instruments, Gaming Sets, and Vehicles
entries: Like skills, each tool, instrument, gaming set, and vehicle is also associated with a particular ability. For example, someone attempting to use thieves' tools to pick a lock would likely roll a Dexterity ability check, whereas someone attempting to use navigator's tools might be asked to roll Wisdom. Someone attempting to play the flute might roll Charisma, and a person attempting to drive a bicycle through traffic might make a Dexterity check.

Characters and NPCs can have proficiency with tools, instruments, and gaming sets, just as they can in skills. So, the lock picker can add their proficiency bonus to that attempt to pick a lock when using thieves' tools if they have proficiency in thieves' tools. Similarly, someone with proficiency in electronics repair kit can add their proficiency bonus to their Intelligence modifier when attempting to repair a device.

In some cases, the GM might decide to call for a different ability score to be rolled. For example, when piloting an airplane in a dog fight, the GM might call for a Dexterity check. When figuring out how to activate the autopilot, however, they might call for Wisdom or Intelligence instead. If the character has proficiency with Vehicles (Air and Space), then they can add their proficiency bonus to any of these rolls.

entries.name: Time
entries: In situations where the passage of time is important the GM determines the time a task requires. The GM might use a different time scale depending on the context of the situation at hand. In an investigative environment, the heroes' movement happens on a scale of minutes. In a city or wilderness, a scale of hours is often more appropriate. For long journeys, a scale of days works best.
In combat and other fast-paced situations, the game relies on rounds, a 6-second span of time.

entries.name: Movement
entries: The GM can summarize the heroes' movement without calculating exact distances or travel times: "You travel through the city and find the villain's base late in the evening. Even in a dangerous environment, particularly a large base or a cave network, the GM can summarize movement between encounters: "After killing the guard at the entrance to the evil genius stronghold, you consult the schematics of the base, which leads you through miles of echoing corridors to a great spherical experimental chamber with a platform suspended in the middle and reached by a narrow bridge.

Sometimes it's important, though, to know how long it takes to get from one spot to another, whether the answer is in days, hours, or minutes. The rules for determining travel time depend on two factors: the speed and travel pace of the creatures moving and the terrain they're moving over.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Every character and NPC has a speed, which is the distance in feet that they can walk in 1 round. This number assumes short bursts of energetic movement amid a life-threatening situation.

entries.name: Traveling Pace
entries: While traveling, a group of heroes can move at a normal, fast, or slow pace, as shown on the Travel Pace table.

The table states how far the party can move in a period and whether the pace has any effect. A fast pace makes characters less perceptive, while a slow pace makes it possible to sneak around and to search an area more carefully.

entries.name: Marching on Foot
entries: The Travel Pace table assumes that characters travel for 8 hours in day. They can push on beyond that limit, at the risk of {@condition exhaustion}.

For each additional hour of travel beyond 8 hours, the characters cover the distance shown in the Hour column for their pace, and each must make a Constitution save at the end of the hour. The DC is 10 + 1 for each hour past 8 hours. On a failed save, a character suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion} (see Appendix 1).

entries.name: Mounts
entries: For short spans of time (up to an hour), many animals move much faster than humanoids. A mounted character can ride at a gallop for about an hour, covering twice the usual distance for a fast pace.

entries.name: Vehicles
entries: Characters in cars, trains, planes, or ships choose a pace as the situation dictates. Characters in a car can choose to stop and rest or drive through the night but gain a level of {@condition exhaustion}. In some cases, such as trains or passenger ships, the vessel moves at its allotted pace and travelers sleep in cabins avoiding {@condition exhaustion} penalties or any effects from a fast pace or slow pace. Depending on the vessel and the size of the crew, ships might be able to travel for up to 24 hours per day.

entries.caption: Travel Pace Table: Distance traveled per...

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: The travel speeds given in the Travel Pace table assume relatively simple terrain: roads, open grass, or clear corridors. But heroes often face dense forests, deep swamps, rubble-filled streets, steep skyscrapers, and ice-covered ground—all considered difficult terrain. Combat also rarely takes place in bare rooms or on featureless spaces. Rubblestrewn streets, crate-choked warehouses, treacherous staircases—the setting of a typical fight contains difficult terrain.

Every foot of movement in difficult terrain costs 1 extra foot. This rule is true even if multiple things in a space count as difficult terrain. Low furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, and shallow bogs are examples of difficult terrain. The space of another creature, whether hostile or not, also counts as difficult terrain.
You move at half speed in difficult terrain—moving 1 foot in difficult terrain costs 2 feet of speed—so you can cover only half the normal distance in a minute, an hour, or a day

entries.name: Special Types of Movement
entries: Movement through dangerous dungeons or wilderness areas often involves more than simply walking. Heroes might have to climb, crawl, swim, or jump to get where they need to go.

entries.name: Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling
entries: While climbing or swimming, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (2 extra feet in difficult terrain), unless a creature has a climbing or swimming speed. At the GM's option, climbing a slippery vertical surface or one with few handholds requires a successful {@skill Athletics} check.
Similarly, gaining any distance in rough water might require a successful {@skill Athletics} check.

entries.name: Jumping
entries: Your Strength determines how far you can jump.

entries.name: Long Jump
entries: When you make a long jump, you cover a number of feet up to your Strength score if you move at least 10 feet on foot immediately before the jump. When you make a standing long jump, you can leap only half that distance. Either way, each foot you clear on the jump costs a foot of movement.
This rule assumes that the height of your jump doesn't matter, such as a jump across a stream or chasm. At your
GM's option, you must succeed on a DC 10 {@skill Athletics} check to clear a low obstacle (no taller than a quarter of the jump's distance), such as a hedge or low wall. Otherwise, you hit it.
When you land in difficult terrain, you must succeed on a DC 10 {@skill Acrobatics} check to land on your feet. Otherwise, you land {@condition prone}.

entries.name: High Jump
entries: When you make a high jump, you leap into the air a number of feet equal to 3 + your Strength modifier if you move at least 10 feet on foot immediately before the jump. When you make a standing high jump, you can jump only half that distance. Each foot you clear on either jump costs a foot of movement.
You can extend your arms half your height above yourself during the jump. Thus, you can reach above you a distance equal to the height of the jump plus 1½ times your height.

entries.name: The Environment
entries: At times, the work of a superhero can involve delving into places that are dark, dangerous, and deadly. The rules in this section cover some of the most important ways in which heroes interact with the environment in such places.

entries.name: Falling
entries: A fall from a great height is one of the most common hazards facing a hero, as they fight across rooftops of a city. At the end of a fall, a creature takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell to a maximum of {@dice 20d6}. The creature lands {@condition prone} unless it avoids taking damage from the fall.

entries.name: Suffocating
entries: A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds).

When a creature runs out of breath or is choking, it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 round). At the start of its next turn, it drops to 0 HP and is dying, and it can't regain HP or be stabilized until it can breathe again.

entries.name: Vision & Light
entries: The most fundamental tasks of being a superhero—noticing danger, finding hidden clues, hitting an enemy in combat, and targeting a power, to name just a few—rely heavily on a character's ability to see. Darkness and other effects that obscure vision can prove a significant hindrance.

A given area might be lightly or heavily obscured. In a lightly obscured area, such as dim light, patchy fog, or moderate foliage, creatures have disadvantage on {@skill Perception} checks that rely on sight.

A heavily obscured area—such as darkness, opaque fog, or dense foliage—blocks vision entirely. A creature effectively suffers from the {@condition blinded} condition (see Appendix 1) when trying to see something in that area.
The presence or absence of light in an environment creates three categories of illumination: bright light, dim light, and darkness.
Bright light lets most creatures see normally. Even gloomy days provide bright light, as do flashlights, lanterns, fires, and other sources of illumination within a specific radius.

Dim light, also called shadows, creates a lightly obscured area. An area of dim light is usually a boundary between a source of bright light, such as a flashlight, and surrounding darkness. The soft light of twilight and dawn also counts as dim light. A particularly brilliant full moon might bathe the land in dim light.

Darkness creates a heavily obscured area. Characters face darkness outdoors at night (even most moonlit nights), within the confines of an unlit room, or a subterranean hideout, or in an area of superpowered darkness.
{@sense BLINDSIGHT}

A creature with {@sense blindsight} can perceive its surroundings without relying on sight, within a specific radius. Creatures without eyes and creatures with echolocation or heightened senses, such as bats, have this sense.
{@sense DARKVISION}

Within a specified range, a creature with {@sense Darkvision} can see in darkness as if the darkness were dim light, so areas of darkness are only lightly obscured as far as that creature is concerned. However, the creature can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
{@sense TREMORSENSE|MM}

A creature with {@sense tremorsense|MM} can detect and pinpoint the origin of vibrations within a specific radius, provided that the monster and the source of the vibrations are in contact with the same ground or substance. {@sense Tremorsense|MM} can't be used to detect flying or incorporeal creatures.
{@sense TRUESIGHT}

A creature with {@sense truesight} can, out to a specific range, see in both normal and superpowered darkness, see {@condition invisible} creatures and objects, automatically detect visual illusions (succeeding on saves against them), and perceive the original form of a shapechanger or a creature that is transformed by a superpower. Furthermore, the creature can see into the Ethereal Plane.

entries.name: Food & Water
entries: Characters who don't eat or drink suffer the effects of {@condition exhaustion} (see Appendix 1). Exhaustion caused by lack of food or water can't be removed until the character eats and drinks the full required amount.

entries.name: Food
entries: A character needs one pound of food per day and can make food last longer by subsisting on half rations.
Eating half a pound of food in a day counts as half a day without food.
A character can go without food for a number of days equal to 3 + their Constitution modifier (minimum 1).
At the end of each day beyond that limit, a character automatically suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}. A normal day of eating resets the count of days without food to zero.

entries.name: Water
entries: A character needs one gallon of water per day, or two gallons per day if the weather is hot. A character who drinks only half that much water must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution save or suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion} at the end of the day. A character with access to even less water automatically suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion} at the end of the day.
If the character already has one or more levels of {@condition exhaustion}, the character takes two levels in either case.

entries.name: Interacting with Objects
entries: A character's interaction with objects in an environment is often simple to resolve in the game. The player tells the GM that their character is doing something, such as moving a lever, and the GM describes what, if anything, happens.

Characters can also damage objects with their weapons and powers. Objects are immune to poison and psychic damage, but otherwise they can be affected by physical and superpowered attacks much like creatures can. The GM determines an object's Armor Class and HP and might decide that certain objects have resistance or immunity to certain kinds of attacks. (It's hard to cut a rope with a club, for example.) Objects always fail Strength and Dexterity saves, and they are immune to effects that require other saves. When an object drops to 0 HP, it breaks.
A character can also attempt a Strength check to break an object. The GM sets the DC for any such check.

entries.name: Interacting with Objects Around You
entries: Here are a few examples of the sorts of thing you can do in tandem with your movement and action:
Draw or holster one pistol
Open or close a door
Withdraw a first aid kit from your pack
Pick up a dropped weapon
Take a bauble from a table
Remove a ring from your finger
Stuff some food into your mouth
Plant a banner in the ground
Fish a few dollars from your wallet
Drink all the contents of a bottle
Throw a lever or push a button
Turn a flashlight on or off
Take a book from a shelf you can reach
Extinguish a small flame
Don a mask
Put the hood of your hoodie up over your head
Put your ear to a door
Kick a can down the road
Turn a key in a lock
Hand an item to another character

entries.name: Resting
entries: Heroic though they might be superheroes can't spend every hour of the day in the thick of exploration, social interaction, and combat. They need rest—time to sleep and eat, tend their wounds, refresh their minds and spirits for using powers, and brace themselves for further adventure.
Heroes can take short rests amid their day and a long rest to end the day.

entries.name: Short Rest
entries: A short rest is a period of downtime, at least 10 minutes long, during which a character does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending to wounds.

A character can spend one or more Hit Dice at the end of a short rest, up to the character's maximum number of Hit Dice, which is equal to the character's level. For each Hit Die spent in this way, the player rolls the die and adds the character's Constitution modifier to it. The character regains HP equal to the total. The player can decide to spend an additional Hit Die after each roll. A character regains some spent Hit Dice upon finishing a long rest.

entries.name: Long Rest
entries: A long rest is a period of extended downtime, at least 8 hours long, during which a character sleeps or performs light activity: reading, talking, eating, or standing watch for no more than 2 hours. If the rest is interrupted by a period of strenuous activity—at least 1 hour of walking, fighting, using powers, or similar activity—the characters must begin the rest again to gain any benefit from it.

At the end of a long rest, a character regains all lost HP. The character also regains spent Hit Dice, up to a number of dice equal to half of the character's total number of them (minimum of one die).
A character can't benefit from more than one long rest in a 24-hour period, and a character must have at least 1 HP at the start of the rest to gain its benefits.

entries.name: The Order of Combat
entries: A typical combat encounter is a clash between two sides using powers. The game organizes the chaos of combat into a cycle of rounds and turns. A round represents about 6 seconds in the game world. During a round, each participant in a battle takes a turn. The order of turns is determined at the beginning of a combat encounter when everyone rolls initiative. Once everyone has taken a turn, the fight continues to the next round if neither side has defeated the other.

entries.name: Combat Step By Step
entries: {@b 1. Determine surprise}. The GM determines whether anyone involved in the combat encounter is surprised.

{@b 2. Establish positions}. The GM decides where all the characters and villains are located. Given the heroes' marching order or their stated positions in the room or other location, the GM figures out where the adversaries are—how far away and in what direction.
{@b 3. Roll initiative}. Everyone involved in the combat encounter rolls initiative, determining the order of combatants' turns.
{@b 4. Take turns}. Each participant in the battle takes a turn in initiative order.
{@b 5. Begin the next round}. When everyone involved in the combat has had a turn, the round ends. Repeat step 4 until the fighting stops.

entries.name: Surprise & Positions
entries: If a band of heroes sneaks up on a gang hideout, springing from the walkways above to attack them, our heroes gain surprise over the thugs.

The GM determines who might be surprised. If neither side tries to be stealthy, they automatically notice each other. Otherwise, the GM compares the {@skill Stealth} checks of anyone hiding with the passive {@skill Perception} score of each creature on the opposing side. Any character or creature that doesn't notice a threat is surprised at the start of the encounter.

If you're surprised, you can't move or take an action on your first turn of the combat, and you can't take a reaction until that turn ends. A member of a group can be surprised even if the other members aren't.
Additionally, the GM and players decide where everyone is positioned when action freezes for the beginning of a combat.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: Initiative determines who goes when during combat. When combat starts, every participant makes a Dexterity check to determine their place in the initiative order. The GM makes one roll for an entire group of identical creatures, so each member of the group acts at the same time.

The GM ranks the combatants in order from the one with the highest Dexterity check total to the one with the lowest. This is the order (called the initiative order) in which they act during each round. The initiative order remains the same from round to round.

If a tie occurs, the GM decides the order among tied GM-controlled creatures, and the players decide the order among their tied characters. The GM can decide the order if the tie is between an NPC and a PC. Optionally, the GM can have the tied characters and villains each roll a {@dice d20} to determine the order, highest roll going first.

entries.name: A Turn
entries: On your turn, you can move a distance up to your speed and take one action. You decide which one to do first. Your speed—sometimes called your walking speed—is noted on your character sheet. The most common actions you can take are described in the "Actions in Combat" section. Many class features and other abilities provide additional options for your action.
The "Movement & Position" section gives the rules for your move.

You can forgo moving, taking an action, or doing anything at all on your turn. If you can't decide what to do on your turn, consider taking the {@action Dodge} or {@action Ready} action, as described in "Actions in Combat.

entries.name: Bonus Actions
entries: Various class features, powers, and other abilities let you take an additional action on your turn called a bonus action. You can take a bonus action only when a special ability, power, or other feature of the game states that you can do something as a bonus action. You otherwise don't have a bonus action to take.
You can take only one bonus action on your turn, so you must choose which bonus action to use when you have more than one available.

You choose when to take a bonus action during your turn, unless the bonus action's timing is specified, and anything that deprives you of your ability to take actions also prevents you from taking a bonus action.

entries.name: Other Activities on Your Turn
entries: Your turn can include a variety of flourishes that require neither your action nor your move.
You can freely communicate however you are able, through brief utterances and gestures, as you take your turn.

You can also interact with one object or feature of the environment for free, during either your move or your action. For example, you could open a door during your move as you stride toward a foe, or you could draw your weapon as part of the same action you use to attack.
If you want to interact with a second object, you need to use your action. Some devices and other special objects always require an action to use, as stated in their descriptions.

The GM might require you to use an action for any of these activities when it needs special care or when it presents an unusual obstacle. For instance, the GM could reasonably expect you to use an action to open a stuck door or access a computer to enter a command.

entries.name: Reactions
entries: Certain special abilities, powers, and situations allow you to take a special action called a reaction. A reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else's. The opportunity attack is the most common type of reaction.

When you take a reaction, you can't take another one until the start of your next turn. If the reaction interrupts another creature's turn, that creature can continue its turn right after the reaction.

entries.name: Movement & Position
entries: In combat, characters and creatures are in constant motion, often using movement and position to gain the upper hand.
On your turn, you can move a distance up to your speed. You can use as much or as little of your speed as you like on your turn, following the rules here.

Your movement can include jumping, climbing, and swimming. These different modes of movement can be combined with walking, or they can constitute your entire move. Whichever way you're moving, you deduct the distance of each part of your move from your speed until it is used up or until you are done moving.

entries.name: Breaking Up Your Movement
entries: You can split your movement on your turn, using some of your speed before and after your action. For example, if you have a speed of 30 feet, you can move 10 feet, take your action, and then move 20 feet.

entries.name: Moving Between Attacks
entries: If you take an action that includes more than one attack, you can break up your movement even further by moving between those attacks. For example, a hero who can make two attacks with the Extra Attack feature and who has a speed of 30 feet could move 10 feet, make an attack, move 20 feet, and then attack again.

entries.name: Using Different Speeds
entries: If you have more than one speed, such as either your walking or flying speed, you can switch back and forth between your speeds during your move. Whenever you switch, subtract the distance you've already moved from the new speed. The result determines how much farther you can move. If the result is 0 or less, you can't use the new speed during the current move.

entries.name: Being Prone
entries: Combatants often find themselves lying on the ground, either because they are knocked down or because they throw themselves down. In the game, they are {@condition prone}, a condition described more in Appendix 1.
You can drop {@condition prone} without using any of your speed. {@b Standing up} takes more effort; doing so costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed.
You can't stand up if you don't have enough movement left or if your speed is 0.

To move while {@condition prone}, you must {@b crawl} or use a superpower such as teleportation. Crawling costs double normal movement. Crawling 1 foot in difficult terrain, therefore, costs 3 feet of movement.

entries.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
entries: You can move through a nonhostile creature's space. You can only move through a hostile creature's space if the creature is at least two sizes larger or smaller than you. Remember that another creature's space is difficult terrain for you. Whether a creature is a friend or an enemy, you can't willingly end your move in its space.
If you leave a hostile creature's reach during your move, you provoke an opportunity attack.

entries.name: Flying Movement
entries: Flying creatures enjoy many benefits of mobility, but they must also deal with the danger of falling. If a flying creature is knocked {@condition prone}, has its speed reduced to 0, or is otherwise deprived of the ability to move, the creature falls, unless it can hover or it is being held aloft by someone else's superpower, such as by the telekinesis power.

entries.name: Creature Size
entries: Each creature takes up a different amount of space. The Size Categories table shows how much space a creature of a particular size controls in combat. Objects sometimes use the same size categories.

entries.name: Space
entries: A creature's space is the area in feet that it effectively controls in combat, not an expression of its physical dimensions. A typical Medium creature isn't 5 feet wide, for example, but it does control a space that wide. If a Medium henchman stands in a 5-foot-wide doorway, other creatures can't get through unless the thug lets them.

A creature's space also reflects the area it needs to fight effectively. For that reason, there's a limit to the number of creatures that can surround another creature in combat. Assuming Medium combatants, eight creatures can fit in a 5-foot radius around another one.

Because larger creatures take up more space, fewer of them can surround a creature. If five Large creatures crowd around a Medium or smaller one, there's little room for anyone else. In contrast, as many as twenty Medium creatures can surround a Gargantuan one.

entries.name: Squeezing into a Smaller Space
entries: A creature can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature one size smaller than it. Thus, a Large creature can squeeze through a passage that's only 5 feet wide. While squeezing through a space, a creature must spend 1 extra foot for every foot it moves there, and it has disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saves. {@action Attack} rolls against the creature have advantage while it's in the smaller space.

entries.name: Cover
entries: Walls, trees, creatures, and other obstacles can provide cover during combat, making a target more difficult to harm. A target can benefit from cover only when an attack or other effect originates on the opposite side of the cover.

There are three amounts of cover. If a target is behind multiple sources of cover, only the most protective degree of cover applies; the degrees aren't added together. For example, if a target is behind a creature that gives ½ cover and a tree trunk that gives ¾ cover, the target has ¾ cover.

A target with {@b half cover} has a +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saves. A target has ½ cover if an obstacle blocks at least half of its body. The obstacle might be a low wall, a large piece of furniture, a narrow tree trunk, or a creature, whether that creature is an enemy or a friend.

A target with {@b three-quarters cover} has a +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saves. A target has ¾ cover if about ¾ of it is covered by an obstacle. The obstacle might be a mailbox, an arrow slit, or a thick tree trunk.

A target with {@b total cover} can't be targeted directly by an attack or a power (although some powers can reach such a target by including it in an area of effect). A target has total cover if it is completely concealed by an obstacle.

entries.name: Actions in Combat
entries: When you take your action on your turn, you can take one of the actions presented here, an action you gained from your class or a special feature, or an action that you improvise. Many foes have action options of their own in their stat blocks.
When you describe an action not detailed elsewhere in the rules, the GM tells you whether that action is possible and what kind of roll you need to make, if any, to determine success or failure.

entries.name: Attack
entries: The most common action to take in combat is the {@action Attack} action, whether you are swinging a baton, shooting a rifle, using a power to make an attack, or brawling with your fists.
With this action, you make one melee or ranged attack. Certain features, such as the Extra Attack feature of the trained hero, allow you to make more than one attack with this action.

entries.name: Making an Attack
entries: Whether you're striking with a melee weapon, firing a weapon at range, or making an attack roll as part of a power, an attack has a simple structure.
{@b 1. Choose a target}. Pick a target within your attack's range: a creature, an object, or a location.

{@b 2. Determine modifiers}. The GM determines whether the target has cover and whether you have advantage or disadvantage against the target. In addition, powers, special abilities, and other effects can apply penalties or bonuses to your attack roll.

{@b 3. Resolve the attack}. You make the attack roll. On a hit, you roll damage, unless that attack has rules that specify otherwise. (Some attacks cause special effects in addition to or instead of damage.)
If there's ever any question whether something you're doing counts as an attack, the rule is simple: if you're making an attack roll, you're making an attack.

entries.name: Attack Rolls
entries: When you make an attack, your attack roll determines whether the attack hits or misses. To make an attack roll, roll a {@dice d20} and add the appropriate modifiers. If the total of the roll plus modifiers equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class (AC), the attack hits.

entries.name: Modifiers to the Roll
entries: When a character makes an attack roll, the two most common modifiers to the roll are an ability modifier and the character's proficiency bonus. When an NPC makes an attack roll, it uses whatever modifier is provided in its stat block.

entries.name: Ability Modifier
entries: The ability modifier used for a melee weapon attack is Strength, and the ability modifier used for a ranged weapon attack is Dexterity. Weapons that have the finesse or thrown property break this rule.
Some powers also require an attack roll. The ability modifier used for a power attack depends on the power ability of the superhero.

entries.name: Proficiency Bonus
entries: You add your proficiency bonus to your attack roll when you attack using a weapon with which you have proficiency, as well as when you attack with a power.

entries.name: Rolling 1 or 20
entries: Sometimes fate blesses or curses a combatant, causing the novice to hit and the veteran to miss.
If the {@dice d20} roll for an attack is a 20, the attack hits regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC. This is called a critical hit.
If the {@dice d20} roll for an attack is a 1, the attack misses regardless of any modifiers or the target's AC.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action and attack with a light melee or ranged weapon that you're holding in one hand, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different light melee or ranged weapon that you're holding in the other hand. You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack unless that modifier is negative.

entries.name: Unseen Attackers and Targets
entries: Combatants often try to escape their foes' notice by hiding, using an invisibility power, or lurking in darkness.

When you attack a target that you can't see, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. This is true whether you're guessing the target's location or targeting a creature you can hear but not see. If the target isn't in the location you targeted, you automatically miss.

When a creature can't see you, you have advantage on attack rolls against it. If you are hidden—both unseen and unheard—when you make an attack, you give away your location when the attack hits or misses.

entries.name: Ranged Attacks
entries: When you make a ranged attack, you fire a gun, sling superpowered fire, hurl a dagger, or otherwise send projectiles to strike a foe at a distance. Many powers involve making a ranged attack.

entries.name: Range
entries: You can make ranged attacks only against targets within a specified range.
If a ranged attack, such as one made with a power, has a single range, you can't attack a target beyond this range.

Some ranged attacks, such as those made with a rifle or a crossbow, have two ranges. The smaller number is the normal range, and the larger number is the long range. Your attack roll has disadvantage when your target is beyond normal range, and you can't attack a target beyond the long range.

entries.name: Ranged Attacks in Close Combat
entries: Aiming a ranged attack is more difficult when a foe is next to you. When you make a ranged attack with a weapon, a power, or some other means, you have disadvantage on the attack roll if you are within 5 feet of a hostile creature who can see you and who isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Melee Attacks
entries: Used in hand-to-hand combat, a melee attack allows you to attack a foe within your reach. A melee attack typically uses a handheld weapon such as a knife, a baton, or a bayonet. A monstrous foe might make a melee attack when it strikes with its claws, horns, teeth, tentacles, or other body part. Many powers also involve making a melee attack.

Most creatures have a 5-foot reach and can thus attack targets within 5 feet of them when making a melee attack. Certain creatures (typically those larger than Medium) have melee attacks with a greater reach than 5 feet, as noted in their descriptions.

Instead of using a weapon to make a melee weapon attack, you can use an {@b unarmed strike}: a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow (none of which count as weapons). On a hit, an unarmed strike deals bludgeoning damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier. You are always proficient with your unarmed strikes.

entries.name: Opportunity Attacks
entries: In a fight, everyone is watching for a chance to strike an enemy who is fleeing or passing by. Such a strike is called an {@b opportunity attack}.

You can make an opportunity attack when a visible hostile creature moves out of your reach. To make the opportunity attack, you use your {@b reaction} to make one melee attack against the provoking creature. The attack occurs right before the creature leaves your reach.

You can avoid provoking an opportunity attack by taking the {@action Disengage} action. You also don't provoke an opportunity attack when you teleport or when someone or something moves you without using your movement, action, or reaction. For example, you don't provoke an opportunity attack if an explosion hurls you out of a foe's reach or if gravity causes you to fall past an enemy.

entries.name: Contests in Combat
entries: Battle often involves pitting your prowess against that of your foe. Such a challenge is represented by a contest. This section includes the most common contests that require an action in combat: grappling and shoving a creature. The GM can use these contests as models for improvising others.

entries.name: Grappling
entries: When you want to grab a creature or wrestle with it, you can use the {@action Attack} action to make a special melee attack, a grapple. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the {@action Attack} action, this attack replaces one of them.

The target of your grapple must be no more than one size larger than you and must be within your reach. Using at least one free hand, you try to seize the target by making a grapple check instead of an attack roll: an {@skill Athletics} check contested by the target's {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Acrobatics} check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you succeed, you subject the target to the {@condition grappled} condition (see Appendix 1). The condition specifies the things that end it, and you can release the target whenever you like (no action required).

entries.name: Escaping a Grapple
entries: A {@condition grappled} creature can use its action to escape. To do so, it must succeed on an {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Acrobatics} check contested by your {@skill Athletics} check.

entries.name: Moving a Grappled Creature
entries: When you move, you can drag or carry the {@condition grappled} creature with you, but your speed is halved, unless the creature is two or more sizes smaller than you.

entries.name: Shoving a Creature
entries: Using the {@action Attack} action, you can make a special melee attack to {@action shove} a creature, either to knock it {@condition prone} or push it away from you. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the {@action Attack} action, this attack replaces one of them.

The target must be no more than one size larger than you and must be within your reach. Instead of making an attack roll, you make an {@skill Athletics} check contested by the target's {@skill Athletics} or {@skill Acrobatics} check (the target chooses the ability to use). If you win the contest, you either knock the target {@condition prone} or push it 5 feet away from you.

entries.name: Dash
entries: When you take the {@action Dash} action, you gain extra movement for the current turn. The increase equals your speed, after applying any modifiers. With a speed of 30 feet, for example, you can move up to 60 feet on your turn if you dash.

Any increase or decrease to your speed changes this additional movement by the same amount. If your speed of 30 feet is reduced to 15 feet, for instance, you can move up to 30 feet this turn if you dash.

entries.name: Disengage
entries: If you take the {@action Disengage} action, your movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks for the rest of the turn.

entries.name: Dodge
entries: When you take the {@action Dodge} action, you focus entirely on avoiding attacks. Until the start of your next turn, you make Dexterity saves with advantage and any attack roll made against you has disadvantage if you can see the attacker. You lose this benefit if you are {@condition incapacitated} (as explained in Appendix 1) or if your speed drops to 0.

entries.name: Help
entries: You can lend your aid to another creature in the completion of a task. When you take the {@action Help} action, the creature you aid gains advantage on the next ability check it makes to perform the task you are helping with, if it makes the check before the start of your next turn.

Alternatively, you can aid a friendly creature in attacking a creature within 5 feet of you. You feint, distract the target, or in some other way team up to make your ally's attack more effective. If your ally attacks the target before your next turn, the first attack roll is made with advantage.

entries.name: Hide
entries: When you take the {@action Hide} action, you make a {@skill Stealth} check to hide, following the rules for hiding. If you succeed, you gain certain benefits, as described in the "Unseen Attackers and Targets" section.

entries.name: Hiding
entries: The GM decides when circumstances are appropriate for hiding. When you try to hide, make a {@skill Stealth} check. Until you are discovered, or you stop hiding, that check's total is contested by the {@skill Perception} check of any creature that actively searches for signs of your presence.
You can't hide from a creature that can see you clearly, and you give away your position if you make any noise.

An {@condition invisible} creature can always try to hide. Signs of its passage might still be noticed, and it does have to stay quiet. In combat, most creatures stay alert for signs of danger all around, so if you come out of hiding and approach a creature, it usually sees you. However, the GM might allow you to stay hidden as you approach a creature that is distracted, allowing you to gain advantage on an attack roll before you are seen.

entries.name: Passive Perception
entries: When you hide, you might be noticed even if no one is actively searching. To determine being noticed, the GM compares your {@skill Stealth} check with that looker's passive {@skill Perception} score, which equals 10
+ the creature's Wisdom modifier, as well as any other bonuses or penalties. If the creature has advantage, add
5. For disadvantage, subtract 5.

entries.name: What Can You See?
entries: One of the main factors in determining whether you can find a hidden creature or object is how well you can see in an area, which might be lightly or heavily obscured, as explained in "The Environment"

entries.name: Ready
entries: Sometimes you want to get the jump on a foe or wait for a particular circumstance before you act. To do so, you can take the {@action Ready} action on your turn, which lets you act using your reaction before the start of your next turn.

First, you decide what perceivable circumstance will trigger your reaction. Then, you choose the action you will take in response to that trigger, or you choose to move up to your speed in response to it. Examples include "If the goon steps on the trapdoor, I'll pull the lever that opens it," and "If the watchman steps next to me, I move away.
When the trigger occurs, you can either take your reaction right after the trigger finishes or ignore the trigger. Remember that you can take only one reaction per round.

When you ready a power, you use it as normal but hold its energy, which you release with your reaction when the trigger occurs. To be readied, a power must have a use time of 1 action and holding onto the power's energy requires {@status concentration}. If your {@status concentration} is broken, the power dissipates without taking effect. For example, if you are {@status concentration||concentrating} on the web power and ready force missile, your web power ends, and if you take damage before you release force missile with your reaction, your {@status concentration} might be broken.

entries.name: Search
entries: When you take the {@action Search} action, you devote your attention to finding something. Depending on the nature of your search, the GM might have you make a {@skill Perception} check or an {@skill Investigation} check.

entries.name: Use an Object
entries: You normally interact with an object while doing something else, such as when you draw a pistol as part of an attack. When an object requires your action for its use, you take the {@action Use an Object} action during combat. This action is also useful when you want to interact with more than one object on your turn.

entries.name: Use a Power
entries: Superheroes, as well as many villains, have access to powers and can use them to great effect in combat. Each power has a use time, which specifies whether the user must use an action, a reaction, minutes, or even hours to use a power. Using a power is, therefore, not necessarily an action. Most powers do have a use time of 1 action, so a superhero often uses their action in combat to use such a power.

entries.name: Damage & Healing
entries: Injury and the risk of death are constant companions of those who explore RPG worlds. The thrust of a blade, a well-placed bullet, or a blast from powers all have the potential to damage, or even kill, the hardiest of creatures.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: Hit points represent a combination of physical and mental durability, the will to live, and luck. Creatures with more HP are more difficult to kill. Those with fewer HP are more fragile.
A creature's current HP can be any number from the creature's maximum down to 0. This number changes frequently as a creature takes damage or receives healing.
Whenever a creature takes damage, that damage is subtracted from its HP. The loss of HP has no effect on a creature's capabilities until the creature drops to 0 HP.

entries.name: Damage Rolls
entries: Each weapon, power, and harmful ability specifies the damage it deals. You roll the damage die or dice, add any modifiers, and apply the damage to your target. Superpowered weapons, special abilities, and other factors can grant a bonus to damage. With a penalty, it is possible to deal 0 damage, but never negative damage.
When attacking with a weapon, you add your ability modifier—the same modifier used for the attack roll—to the damage. A power tells you which dice to roll for damage and whether to add any modifiers.

If a power or other effect deals damage to more than one target at the same time, roll the damage once for all of them. For example, when someone uses a grenade, the power's damage is rolled once for all creatures caught in the blast.

entries.name: Critical Hits
entries: When you score a critical hit, you get to roll extra dice for the attack's damage against the target. Roll all the attack's damage dice twice and add them together. Then add any relevant modifiers as normal. To speed up play, you can roll all the damage dice at once.

entries.name: Damage Types
entries: Different attacks, damaging powers, and other harmful effects deal different types of damage. Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as damage resistance, rely on the types.
The damage types follow, with examples to help a GM assign a damage type to a new effect.

entries.name: Acid
entries: The corrosive liquids used in some manufacturing processes, as well as the dissolving enzymes secreted digestive tracks, deal acid damage.

entries.name: Bludgeoning
entries: Blunt force attacks—hammers, falling, constriction, and the like—deal bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Cold
entries: The damage one suffers in the low temperatures of the arctic or in a deep freezer is cold damage.

entries.name: Fire
entries: A burning building or an explosion might deal fire damage.

entries.name: Force
entries: Force is pure energy focused into a damaging form. Most effects that deal force damage are powers, including force missile and unerring projectile.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: A lightning bolt power and a high voltage power line deal lightning damage.

entries.name: Necrotic
entries: Necrotic damage, the power of decay and rot, which is dealt by certain undead creatures, withers matter and even one's consciousness.

entries.name: Piercing
entries: Puncturing and impaling attacks, including arrows and bullets, deal piercing damage.

entries.name: Poison
entries: Venomous stings and the toxic fumes of a gas attack deal poison damage.

entries.name: Psychic
entries: Mental abilities such as a telepath's attacks can deal psychic damage.

entries.name: Radiant
entries: Radiant damage, dealt by a laser blast or laser sword, sears the flesh like fire and overloads the spirit with power.

entries.name: Slashing
entries: Swords, chainsaws, and monstrous claws deal slashing damage.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: A concussive burst of sound, such as the effect of the thunderwave power, deals thunder damage.

entries.name: Damage Resistance & Vulnerability
entries: Some creatures and objects are exceedingly difficult or unusually easy to hurt with certain types of damage.

If a creature or an object has resistance to a damage type, damage of that type is halved against it. If a creature or an object has vulnerability to a damage type, damage of that type is doubled against it.
Resistance and then vulnerability are applied after all other modifiers to damage. Multiple instances of resistance or vulnerability that affect the same damage type count as only one instance.

For example, a creature has resistance to bludgeoning damage and is hit by an attack that deals 25 bludgeoning damage. The creature is also within a superpowered aura that reduces all damage by 5. The 25 damage is first reduced by 5 and then halved, so the creature takes 10 damage.
Or, if a creature has resistance to fire damage, the damage is reduced by ½ against the creature, not reduced by ¾.
If a creature's stat block indicates it has resistance or immunity to "non-magical" bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, count damage caused by powers as if it were magical damage.

entries.name: Healing
entries: Unless it results in death, damage isn't permanent. Even death is reversible through superpowers or magic. Rest can restore a creature's HP, and superpowered methods such as a cure wounds can remove damage in an instant.

When a creature receives healing of any kind, HP regained are added to its current HP. A creature's HP can't exceed its hit point maximum, so any HP regained above this number are lost. A creature that has died can't regain HP until a power such as the revivify power has restored it to life.

entries.name: Dropping to 9 Hit Points
entries: When you drop to 0 HP, you either die outright or fall {@condition unconscious}, as explained in the following sections.

entries.name: Instant Death
entries: Massive damage can kill you instantly. When damage reduces you to 0 HP and there is damage remaining, you die if the remaining damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum.

entries.name: Falling Unconscious
entries: If damage reduces you to 0 HP and fails to kill you, you fall {@condition unconscious} (see Appendix 1). This unconsciousness ends if you regain any HP.

entries.name: Death Saving Throws
entries: Whenever you start your turn with 0 HP, you must make a special saving throw, called a {@b death saving throw}, to determine whether you creep closer to death or hang onto life. Unlike other saves, this one isn't tied to any ability score. You are in the hands of fate now, aided only by powers and features that improve your chances of succeeding on a saving throw.
{@i Each turn you may roll a {@dice d20}. If the roll is 10 or higher, you gain one success. Otherwise, you collect one failure. A success or failure has no effect by itself.}

On your third success, you become stable (see below). On your third failure, you die. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of both until you collect three of a kind. The number of both is reset to zero when you regain any HP or become stable.

entries.name: Rolling 1 or 20
entries: When you make a death save and roll a 1 on the {@dice d20}, it counts as two failures. If you roll a 20 on the {@dice d20}, you regain 1 hit point.

entries.name: Damage at 0 Hit Points
entries: If you take any damage while you have 0 HP, you suffer a death save failure. If the damage is from a critical hit, you suffer two failures instead. If the damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum, you suffer instant death.

entries.name: Stabilizing a Creature
entries: The best way to save a creature with 0 HP is to heal it. If healing is unavailable, the creature can at least be stabilized so that it isn't killed by a failed death save.
You can use your action to administer first aid to an {@condition unconscious} creature and attempt to stabilize it, which requires a successful DC 10 {@skill Medicine} check.

A {@b stable} creature doesn't make death saving throws, even though it has 0 HP, but it does remain {@condition unconscious}. The creature stops being stable, and must start making death saves again, if it takes any damage. A stable creature that isn't healed regains 1 hit point after {@dice 1d4} hours.

entries.name: Knocking a Creature Out
entries: Sometimes an attacker wants to incapacitate a foe, rather than deal a killing blow. When an attacker reduces a creature to 0 HP with a melee attack, the attacker can knock the creature out. The attacker can make this choice the instant the damage is dealt. The creature falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable.

entries.name: Temporary Hit Points (HP)
entries: Some powers and special abilities confer temporary HP to a creature. Temporary HP aren't actual Hit Points; they are a buffer against damage, a pool of HP that protect you from injury.

When you have temporary HP and take damage, the temporary HP are lost first, and any leftover damage carries over to your normal HP. Because temporary HP are separate from your actual HP, they can exceed your hit point maximum. A character can, therefore, be at full HP and receive temporary HP.
Healing can't restore temporary HP, and they can't be added together. If you have temporary HP and receive more of them, you decide whether to keep the ones you have or to gain the new ones.

If you have 0 HP, receiving temporary HP doesn't restore you to consciousness or stabilize you. They can still absorb damage directed at you while you're in that state, but only true healing can save you.
Unless a feature that grants you temporary HP has a duration, they last until they're depleted, or you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Vehicular Combat
entries: A Special Agent charging into battle on a motorcycle, an Elementalist slinging powers from the back of a truck, or a Mystic soaring through the sky in a helicopter all enjoy the benefits of speed and mobility that a vehicle can provide.

entries.name: Getting Into & Out of a Vehicle
entries: Once during your move, you can enter a vehicle that is within 5 feet of you or exit one you're in. Doing so costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed. For example, if your speed is 30 feet, you must spend 15 feet of movement to mount a motorcycle. Therefore, you can't mount it if you don't have 15 feet of movement left or if your speed is 0.

entries.name: Vehicles and Being Knocked Prone
entries: Some vehicles you ride on rather than within, such as a bicycle or motorcycle. You are more vulnerable to being knocked off such vehicles. If an effect moves your vehicle against your will while you're on it, you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity save or fall off the vehicle, landing {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet of it. If you're knocked {@condition prone} while mounted, you must make the same save.

If your vehicle is one or two wheeled, it can also be knocked {@condition prone}. If the vehicle is targeted with an effect that knocks it {@condition prone} which requires a save, the driver must succeed on a DC 10 save or they lose control of the vehicle, and it falls over. If your vehicle is knocked {@condition prone}, you can use your reaction to jump off it as it falls and land on your feet. Otherwise, you are thrown from the vehicle and fall {@condition prone} in a space within 5 feet it.
Vehicles with four or more wheels cannot be knocked {@condition prone} easily, though they can be flipped in extreme circumstances if the GM decides.

entries.name: Controlling A Vehicle
entries: While you're in a vehicle, you have two options. You can either control the vehicle or allow it to move without steering.

To control a vehicle through exceptionally challenging circumstances or difficult terrain, such as a superpowered sleet storm, the GM may call for a Dexterity check. To avoid crashing into a sudden obstacle or to dodge an explosion, the GM may call for a Dexterity save.
If you pilot or ride in a vehicle and move away from a foe, this provokes an opportunity attack. The attacker can target you or the vehicle.

entries.name: Combat In & With Vehicles
entries: When characters wish to make an attack from a moving vehicle, the rules apply as normal. If the vehicle is moving quickly and the target is stationary or moving in a different direction, however, the GM may decide to apply disadvantage on the roll, to account for the difficulty of hitting a target under those conditions.

entries.name: Attacking From a Moving Vehicle
entries: If characters wish to attack someone within a vehicle, the GM decides how much cover, if any, the target has. Someone driving a motorcycle has no cover, though the GM might decide that the attack has disadvantage because the motorcycle is moving at high speed and the attacker is stationary, making the motorcycle harder to hit. Someone in a car might have three-quarter cover and someone in a tank or inside a train has total cover.
Note that an attacker must break a window before being able to hit a passenger. To do so, the attacker must overcome the damage resistance of the vehicle to break the glass.

entries.name: Attacking a Target Inside a Moving Vehicle
entries: If the vehicle is stationary and there is nothing interfering with the character, assume the vehicle has an AC of 10.If the vehicle is moving, the GM may decide to apply disadvantage to the roll, depending on how fast it is moving relative to the attacker.

entries.name: Attacking a Vehicle Itself
entries: If the vehicle is stationary and there is nothing interfering with the character, assume the vehicle has an AC of 10.If the vehicle is moving, the GM may decide to apply disadvantage to the roll, depending on how fast it is moving relative to the attacker.

entries.name: Attacking With a Vehicle
entries: Sometimes a character might choose to ram another character or vehicle. The pilot or driver must make a Dexterity check to steer the vehicle most effectively into the collision. On impact, the GM must determine a damage amount, based on the speed of the vehicles and their relative size and weight. Generally, the larger the vehicle and faster it is moving on impact, the more damage it does. What's more, if the ramming vehicle is larger than its target, the damage increases.

To calculate damage, use the following rules. For every 10 mph faster that the rammer is traveling than its target, it does {@damage 1d10} bludgeoning damage. For every step up in Size the rammer is than its target, the damage doubles.

entries.name: Underwater Combat
entries: When heroes pursue a submarine beneath the waves, fight off sharks around an underwater base, or find themselves in a flooded room, they must fight in a challenging environment. Underwater the following rules apply.

When making a melee weapon attack, a creature that doesn't have a swimming speed (either natural or granted by a superpower) has disadvantage on the attack roll unless the weapon does piercing damage.

A ranged weapon attack automatically misses a target beyond the weapon's normal range. Even against a target within normal range, the attack roll has disadvantage unless the weapon is a crossbow, a net, or a weapon that is thrown like a javelin (including a spear, trident, or dart). Creatures and objects that are fully immersed in water have resistance to fire damage.

data.name: Superpowers
entries: Here are the rules for using powers. Different character classes have distinctive ways of learning and choosing their powers, and NPCs use powers in unique ways. Regardless of its source, a power follows the rules here.

entries.name: What Is a Power?
entries: A power is a discrete, extraordinary effect, a single shaping of the laws of the universe into a specific, limited expression. In using a power, a character channels the ebb and flow of natural forces through themselves or their technology, fixes their existence into a discrete arrangement, sets them vibrating in a specific way, and then releases them to unleash the desired effect—in most cases, all in the span of seconds.
Powers can be versatile tools, weapons, or protective wards. They can deal damage or undo it, impose, or remove conditions (see Appendix 1), drain life energy away, and restore life to the dead.

As many powers as we currently know, myriad more have been forgotten over the course of history. Some may well have served as the basis for our ancient mythologies. Or they might someday be reinvented by a character who has amassed enough power to do so.

entries.name: Superpower Lists
entries: A superpower list is a collection of powers associated with one of the classes, such as Elementalist or Mystic. There is also a General Powers list, available to all heroes with powers. When players create their superheroes, they select a number of these powers from the available lists to define the distinctive combination of abilities that their hero exhibits.

When character choose their powers, either at character creation or when leveling up, they must select from the powers offered in their superpower lists. In general, choosing a character's class determines which lists a hero has available to them, which in turn determines what powers will be available to the character at each level.

entries.name: Power Level
entries: Every power has a level from 0 to 9. A power's level is a general indicator of how powerful it is, with the lowly (but still impressive) force missile at 1st level and the earthshaking wish at 9th. At will powers—simple but potent powers that characters can use innately—are level 0. The higher a power's level, the higher level a superhero must be to use that power.
Power level and character level don't correspond directly, however. Typically, a character must be at least 17th level, not 9th level, to use a 9th-level power.

entries.name: Known & Prepared Powers
entries: Before a superhero can use a power, they must have the power firmly fixed in mind, or must have access to the power in a piece of technology or an artifact. Elemental, Kinetic, Mentalist, Metamorph, and Mystic heroes have a limited list of powers always fixed in mind they know. Tech and Vitalist heroes, however, undergo a process of selecting their powers by modifying their tech.
The number of powers any hero can have fixed in mind at any given time depends on the character's level and is explained in the class descriptions.

entries.name: Power Slots
entries: Regardless of how many powers a hero knows or prepares, they can use only a limited number of powers before resting. Manipulating the fabric of reality and channeling its energy into even a simple power is physically and mentally taxing, and higher-level powers even more so. Thus, each class' description (except those of the Martial Expert, Mastermind, and Special Agent, who have no superpowers) includes a table showing how many power slots of each power level a character can use at each character level.

When a character uses a power, they expend a slot of that power's level or higher, effectively "filling" a slot with the power. You can think of a power slot as a groove of a certain size—small for a 1st-level slot, larger for a power of higher level. A 1st-level power fits into a slot of any size, but a 9th-level power fits only in a 9th-level slot. You regain all expended 1st through 8th level slots when you finish a short or long rest. You regain any expended 9th level power slots when you complete a long rest.

At a certain level, heroes gain the ability to use powers without using slots. For example, a 3rd-level hero gains the ability to use 1st level powers that they know reflexively, which means at will, without needing to worry about expending slots.

entries.name: Using a Power At a Higher Level
entries: When a superhero uses a power by expending a slot that is of a higher level than the level listed with the power, the power assumes the higher level for that use. For instance, if Umara uses force missile using one of her 2nd-level slots, that force missile is 2nd level. Effectively, the power expands to fill the slot it is put into.
Some powers, such as {@spell force missile|Superheroic5E} and {@spell cure wounds}, have more powerful effects when used at a higher level, as detailed in a power's description

entries.name: At Will Powers
entries: At will powers are powers that can be used without expending a slot and without being prepared in advance. Repeated practice has fixed the power in the hero's mind and infused the user with the energies needed to produce the effect over and over. An at will power's power level is 0.

entries.name: Reflexive Powers
entries: At certain levels, each class with superpowers grants you some reflexive powers.

When a superpowered class feature says that a power level is reflexive for you, that means that you may use that power at a level at which you can use powers reflexively without expending a slot. If you wish to use that power at a level for which you have power slots, you must expend a slot as normal.
Therefore, when a hero reaches the 3rd-level, they can use powers that they know or have prepared at the 1st-level reflexively.

As your heroes level up, the levels at which they can use their powers reflexively also increases. At 7th level, for example, heroes can use powers at the 2nd level reflexively as well as at the 1st level.

Consult the class features and charts to see when heroes gain the ability to use powers reflexively. For heroes with power slots, levels at which heroes can use powers reflexively are marked on the chart with an ∞.
Heroes can always choose to use their reflexive powers at a higher level than they have reflexive power slots, but they must expend a normal slot to do so.
Once a hero has expended all their slots, they may still use their at will and reflexive powers.

entries.name: Rituals
entries: Certain powers have a special tag: "ritual. Such a power can be used following the normal rules for superpowers, or the power can be used as a ritual. The ritual version of a power takes 10 minutes longer to use than normal. It also doesn't expend a power slot, which means the ritual version of a power can't be used at a higher level.
To use a power as a ritual, a hero must have a feature that grants the ability to do so. The Mystic hero's invocation intuitions of ancient secrets, for example, is such a feature.

entries.name: Using A Power
entries: When a character uses any power, the same basic rules are followed, regardless of the character's class or the power's effects.
Each power description begins with a block of information, including the power's name, level, use time, range, and duration. The rest of a power's entry describes the effect.

entries.name: Use Time
entries: Most powers require a single action to use, but some powers require a bonus action, a reaction, or much longer time to use.

entries.name: Powers as a Bonus Action
entries: A power used with a bonus action is especially swift. You must use a bonus action on your turn to use the power, if you haven't already taken a bonus action this turn. You can't use another power during the same turn, except for an at will power with a use time of 1 action.

entries.name: Powers as Reactions
entries: Some powers can be used as reactions. These powers take a fraction of a second to bring about and are used in response to some trigger. If a power can be used as a reaction, the power description tells you exactly when you may do so.

entries.name: Longer Use Times
entries: Certain powers (including those used as rituals) require more time to use, minutes or even hours. When you use a power with a use time longer than a single action or reaction, you must spend your action each turn using the power, and you must maintain your {@status concentration} while you do so (see "Concentration" below). If your {@status concentration} is broken, the power fails, but you don't expend a slot. If you want to try using the power again, you must start over.

entries.name: Powers' Range
entries: The target of a power must be within the power's range. For a power like {@spell force missile}Superheroic5E}, the target is a creature. For a power like {@spell fireball}, the target is the point in space where the ball of fire erupts.

Most powers have ranges expressed in feet. Some powers can target only a creature (including you) that you touch. Other powers, such as the {@spell shield} power, affect only you and have a range of "self.
Powers that create cones or lines of effect that originate from you also have a range of self, indicating that the origin point of the power's effect must be you (see "Areas of Effect").
Once a power is used, its effects aren't limited by its range, unless the power's description says otherwise.

entries.name: Customizing Powers
entries: With the GM's approval, players may elect to customize their powers to better fit their heroes. For example:

Changeling is a Mystic hero with the Eldritch Mystic path who has the hellish rebuke power, but she thinks that it should do cold damage rather than fire, to reflect the cold vacuum of space beyond the stars where her eldritch gods reside. With her GM's approval, her hellish rebuke always does cold damage rather than fire. The easiest way to customize a superpower to fit your hero is to change the damage type, as in the case of hellish rebuke. Make your hero unique!

entries.name: Duration
entries: A power's duration is the length of time the power persists. A duration can be expressed in rounds, minutes, hours, or even years. Some powers specify that their effects last until the powers are dispersed or destroyed.

entries.name: Instantaneous
entries: Many powers are instantaneous. The power harms, heals, creates, or alters a target in a way that can't be dispersed, because its power exists only for an instant.

entries.name: Concentration
entries: Some powers require you to maintain {@status concentration} to keep their energy active. If you lose {@status concentration}, such powers end.

If a power must be maintained with {@status concentration}, that fact appears in its Duration entry, and the power specifies how long you can concentrate on it. You can end {@status concentration} at any time (no action required).
Normal activity, such as moving and attacking, doesn't interfere with {@status concentration}. The following factors can break {@status concentration}:

items: {@b Using another power that requires {@status concentration}}.You can't concentrate on two powers at once. You lose {@status concentration} on a power if you use another power that requires {@status concentration}.

{@b Taking damage}. Whenever you take damage while you are {@status concentration||concentrating} on a power, you must make a Constitution save to see if you maintain your {@status concentration}. The DC equals 10 or half the damage you take, whichever number is higher. If you take damage from multiple sources, such as an arrow and a dragon's breath, you make a separate save for each source of damage.
{@b Being {@condition incapacitated} or killed}. You lose {@status concentration} on a power if you are {@condition incapacitated} or if you die.

entries: The GM might also decide that certain environmental phenomena, such as a wave crashing over you while you're on a storm-tossed ship, require you to succeed on a DC 10 Constitution save to maintain {@status concentration} on a power

entries.name: Targets
entries: A typical power requires you to pick one or more targets to be affected by the power's energy. A power's description tells you whether the power targets creatures, objects, or a point of origin for an area of effect (described below).
